{"SLR NAME":"Prevalence of depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder in health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic: a systematic review and meta-analysis","SlR References":[{"doi":"10.1177/2192568220928032","date":"1970-01-01","title":"COVID-19 Impact Among Spine Surgeons in Latin America","abstract":"Study Design:\nCross-sectional study.\n\n\nObjective:\nThe aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak in spine surgeons in Latin America.\n\n\nMethods:\nA questionnaire was sent to Latin American spine surgeons from April 4 to 6, 2020. Surgeon characteristics were recorded.\n\n The impact of COVID-19 on economic well-being, work, and mental health were also determined.\n\n All variables were compared and analyzed.\n\n\nResults:\nTwo hundred four surgeons answered the complete survey; most of them were male (96.6%), the average age was 47.7 years; 58.8% (n = 120) were orthopedic surgeons and 41.2% (n = 84) were neurosurgeons.\n\n The majority of the respondents were from Argentina (59.8%, n = 122), followed by Brazil (17.2%, n = 35), Chile (6.4%, n = 13), and Mexico (5.9%, n = 12).\n\n Most of the surgeons reported performing emergency procedures only during the pandemic (76.5%, n = 156).\n\n Half used telemedicine or online consultation modalities (54.4%, n = 111).\n\n The average concern about the financial situation due to the pandemic was 7.53 in a scale of 1 to 10 (10 being the worst scenario).\n\n Twenty-two percent (n = 45) of the surgeons had a score over 10 in the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9; scores higher than 10 needs referral to confirm depression diagnosis).\n\n Young age and neurosurgery as a specialty were associated with higher PHQ-9 scores.\n\n\nConclusions:\nCOVID-19 has an impact in the daily working practice and financial situation of spine surgeons in Latin America.\n\n The long-term psychological impact should be taken into consideration to avoid a heavier burden for health care providers.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8258821","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC_CROSSREF","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Alfredo","surname":"Guiroy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Martín","surname":"Gagliardi","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Martín","surname":"Gagliardi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nicolas","surname":"Coombes","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Federico","surname":"Landriel","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Federico","surname":"Landriel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Carlos","surname":"Zanardi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gastón Results from an epidemiological study","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jad.2006.05.005","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Treatment adequacy of anxiety and depressive disorders: primary versus specialised care in Spain","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0105471","date":"2014-07-24","title":"Cost of Disorders of the Brain in Spain","abstract":"Background\nBrain disorders represent a high burden in Europe and worldwide.\n\n The objective of this study was to provide specific estimates of the economic costs of brain disorders in Spain, based on published epidemiological and economic evidence.\n\n\nMethods\nA cost-of-illness study with a societal perspective of 19 brain disorders was carried out.\n\n Cost data published between 2004 and 2012 was obtained from a systematic literature review.\n\n Direct healthcare, direct non-medical and indirect costs were considered, prioritizing bottom-up information.\n\n All costs were converted to Euro and to year 2010. The missing values were imputed with European estimates.\n\n Sensitivity analyses based on qualitative assessment of the literature and on a Monte Carlo simulation were performed.\n\n\nResults\nThe review identified 33 articles with information on costs for 11 disorders (8 neurological, 3 mental).\n\n The average perpatient cost ranged from 36,946  for multiple sclerosis to 402  for headache.\n\n The societal cost of the 19 brain disorders in Spain in 2010 was estimated in 84  billion.\n\n Societal costs ranged from 15  billion for dementia to 65  million for eating disorders.\n\n Mental disorders societal cost were 46  billions (55% of the total), while neurological disorder added up to 38  billion.\n\n Healthcare costs represented 37% of the societal costs of brain disorders, whereas direct non-medical constituted 29% and indirect costs 33%.\n\n\nConclusion\nBrain disorders have a substantial economic impact in Spain (equivalent to almost 8% of the country's GDP).\n\n Economic data on several important brain disorders, specially mental disorders, is still sparse.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4136914","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Oleguer","surname":"Parés-Badell","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gabriela","surname":"Barbaglia","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Petra","surname":"Jerinic","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anders","surname":"Gustavsson","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Luis","surname":"Salvador-Carulla","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jordi","surname":"Alonso","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guglielmo","surname":"Foffani","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Guglielmo","surname":"Foffani","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/eurpub/cks035","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The screening and diagnosis in east Africa","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2296-11-63","date":"2010-09-01","title":"A study of the diagnostic accuracy of the PHQ-9 in primary care elderly","abstract":"Background\nThe diagnostic accuracy of the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) for assessment of depression in elderly persons in primary care settings in the United States has not been previously addressed.\n\n Thus, the purpose of this study was to evaluate the test performance of the PHQ-9 for detecting major and minor depression in elderly patients in primary care.\n\n\nMethods\nA prospective study of diagnostic accuracy was conducted in two primary care, university-based clinics in the Pacific Northwest of the United States.\n\n Seventy-one patients aged 65 years or older participated; all completed the PHQ-9 and the 15-item Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) and underwent the Structured Clinical Interview for Depression (SCID).\n\n Sensitivity, specificity, area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, and likelihood ratios (LRs) were calculated for the PHQ-9, the PHQ-2, and the 15-item GDS for major depression alone and the combination of major plus minor depression.\n\n\nResults\nTwo thirds of participants were female, with a mean age of 78 and two chronic health conditions.\n\n Twelve percent met SCID criteria for major depression and 13% minor depression.\n\n The PHQ-9 had an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.87 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.74-1.00) for major depression, while the PHQ-2 and the 15-item GDS each had an AUC of 0.81 (95% CI for PHQ-2, 0.64-0.98, and for 15-item GDS, 0.70-0.91; P = 0.551).\n\n For major and minor depression combined, the AUC for the PHQ-9 was 0.85 (95% CI, 0.73-0.96), for the PHQ-2, 0.80 (95% CI, 0.68-0.93), and for the 15-item GDS, 0.71 (95% CI, 0.55-0.87; P = 0.187).\n\n\nConclusions\nBased on AUC values, the PHQ-9 performs comparably to the PHQ-2 and the 15-item GDS in identifying depression among primary care elderly.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2940814","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Phelan","email":"phelane@u.washington.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Barbara","surname":"Williams","email":"bwilliam@u.washington.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kathryn","surname":"Meeker","email":"kathrynmeeker@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Katie","surname":"Bonn","email":"kbonn@u.washington.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"John","surname":"Frederick","email":"john.frederick@vmmc.org","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"James","surname":"LoGerfo","email":"logerfo@u.washington.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mark","surname":"Snowden","email":"snowden@u.washington.edu","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jad.2014.06.003","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Validity found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1192/bjpo.bp.115.001685","date":"2015-12-21","title":"Case finding and screening clinical utility of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9 and PHQ-2) for depression in primary care: a diagnostic meta-analysis of 40 studies","abstract":"Background\nThe Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) is the most commonly used measure to screen for depression in primary care but there is still lack of clarity about its accuracy and optimal scoring method.\n\n\nAims\nTo determine via meta-analysis the diagnostic accuracy of the PHQ-9-linear, PHQ-9-algorithm and PHQ-2 questions to detect major depressive disorder (MDD) among adults.\n\n\nMethod\nWe systematically searched major electronic databases from inception until June 2015. Articles were included that reported the accuracy of PHQ-9 or PHQ-2 questions for diagnosing MDD in primary care defined according to standard classification systems.\n\n We carried out a meta-analysis, meta-regression, moderator and sensitivity analysis.\n\n\nResults\nOverall, 26 publications reporting on 40 individual studies were included representing 26 902 people (median 502, s.\n\nd.\n\n=693.7) including 14 760 unique adults of whom 14.3% had MDD.\n\n The methodological quality of the included articles was acceptable.\n\n The meta-analytic area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of the PHQ-9-linear and the PHQ-2 was significantly higher than the PHQ-9-algorithm, a difference that was maintained in head-to-head meta-analysis of studies.\n\n Our best estimates of sensitivity and specificity were 81.3% (95% CI 71.689.3) and 85.3% (95% CI 81.089.1), 56.8% (95% CI 41.271.8) and 93.3% (95% CI 87.597.3) and 89.3% (95% CI 81.595.1) and 75.9% (95% CI 70.181.3) for the PHQ-9-linear, PHQ-9-algorithm and PHQ-2 respectively.\n\n For case finding (ruling in a diagnosis), none of the methods were suitable but for screening (ruling out non-cases), all methods were encouraging with good clinical utility, although the cut-off threshold must be carefully chosen.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe PHQ can be used as an initial first step assessment in primary care and the PHQ-2 is adequate for this purpose with good acceptability.\n\n However, neither the PHQ-2 nor the PHQ-9 can be used to confirm a clinical diagnosis (case finding).\n\n\nDeclaration of interest\nNone.\n\n\nCopyright and usage\n© The Royal College of Psychiatrists 2016. This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Non-Commercial, No Derivatives (CC BY-NC-ND) found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/resprot.6351","date":"2016-10-22","title":"Transdiagnostic Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Versus Treatment as Usual in Adult Patients With Emotional Disorders in the Primary Care Setting (PsicAP Study): Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial","abstract":"Background\nDemand for primary care (PC) services in Spain exceeds available resources.\n\n Part of this strong demand is due to the high prevalence of emotional disorders (EDs)anxiety, depression, and somatic symptom disordersand related comorbidities such as pain or chronic illnesses.\n\n EDs are often under- or misdiagnosed by general practitioners (GPs) and, consequently, treatment is frequently inadequate.\n\n\nObjective\nWe aim to compare the short- and long-term effectiveness of group-delivered transdiagnostic cognitive behavioral therapy (TD-CBT) versus treatment as usual (TAU) in the treatment of EDs in the PC setting in Spain.\n\n We also aim to compare the effect of these treatments on disability, quality of life, cognitive-emotional factors, and treatment satisfaction.\n\n\nMethods\nHere we present the study design of a two-arm, single-blind, randomized controlled trial (N=1126) to compare TAU to TD-CBT for EDs.\n\n TAU will consist primarily of pharmacological treatment and practical advice from the GP while TD-CBT will be administered in seven 90-minute group sessions held over a period ranging from 12 to 14 weeks.\n\n Psychological assessments are carried out at baseline (ie, pretreatment); posttreatment; and at 3-, 6-, and 12-month follow-up.\n\n The study is conducted in approximately 26 PC centers from the National Health System in Spain.\n\n\nResults\nThis study was initiated in December 2013 and will remain open to new participants until recruitment and follow-up has been completed.\n\n We expect all posttreatment evaluations to be completed by December 2017, and follow-up will end in December 2018.\nConclusions\nWe expect the TD-CBT group to have better results compared to TAU on all posttreatment measures and that this improvement will be maintained during follow-up.\n\n This project could serve as a model for use in other areas or services of the National Health System in Spain and even in other countries.\n\n\nClinicalTrial\nInternational Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Number (ISRCTN): 58437086; http://www.\n\nisrctn.\n\ncom/ISRCTN58437086 (Archived by WebCite at Primary care evaluation of mental disorders. Patient health questionnaire","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1477-7525-8-8","date":"2010-01-20","title":"Cultural adaptation into Spanish of the generalized anxiety disorder-7 (GAD-7) scale as a screening tool","abstract":"Background\nGeneralized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a prevalent mental health condition which is underestimated worldwide.\n\n This study carried out the cultural adaptation into Spanish of the 7-item self-administered GAD-7 scale, which is used to identify probable patients with GAD.\n\n\nMethods\nThe adaptation was performed by an expert panel using a conceptual equivalence process, including forward and backward translations in duplicate.\n\n Content validity was assessed by interrater agreement.\n\n Criteria validity was explored using ROC curve analysis, and sensitivity, specificity, predictive positive value and negative value for different cut-off values were determined.\n\n Concurrent validity was also explored using the HAM-A, HADS, and WHO-DAS-II scales.\n\n\nResults\nThe study sample consisted of 212 subjects (106 patients with GAD) with a mean age of 50.38 years (SD = 16.76).\n\n Average completion time was 2'30''.\n\n No items of the scale were left blank.\n\n Floor and ceiling effects were negligible.\n\n No patients with GAD had to be assisted to fill in the questionnaire.\n\n The scale was shown to be one-dimensional through factor analysis (explained variance = 72%).\n\n A cut-off point of 10 showed adequate values of sensitivity (86.8%) and specificity (93.4%), with AUC being statistically significant [AUC = 0.957-0.985); p &lt; 0.001].\n\n The scale significantly correlated with HAM-A (0.852, p &lt; 0.001), HADS (anxiety domain, 0.903, p &lt; 0.001), and WHO-DAS II (0.696, p &gt; 0.001).\n\n\nLimitations\nElderly people, particularly those very old, may need some help to complete the scale.\n\n\nConclusion\nAfter the cultural adaptation process, a Spanish version of the GAD-7 scale was obtained.\n\n The validity of its content and the relevance and adequacy of items in the Spanish cultural context were confirmed.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2831043","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Javier","surname":"García-Campayo","email":"jgarcamp@arrakis.es","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Enric","surname":"Zamorano","email":"ezamoranob@semergen.es","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Miguel A","surname":"Ruiz","email":"miguel.ruiz@uam.es","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Pardo","email":"antonio.pardo@uam.es","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"María","surname":"Pérez-Páramo","email":"maria.perez2@pfizer.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Vanessa","surname":"López-Gómez","email":"vanessa.lopez.gomez@pfizer.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Olga","surname":"Freire","email":"olga.freire@pfizer.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Javier","surname":"Rejas","email":"Javier.rejas@pfizer.com","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"First M, Spitzer R, Gibbon M, Williams J. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2105-12-77","date":"2011-03-17","title":"pROC: an open-source package for R and S+ to analyze and compare ROC curves","abstract":"Background\nReceiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves are useful tools to evaluate classifiers in biomedical and bioinformatics applications.\n\n However, conclusions are often reached through inconsistent use or insufficient statistical analysis.\n\n To support researchers in their ROC curves analysis we developed pROC, a package for R and S+ that contains a set of tools displaying, analyzing, smoothing and comparing ROC curves in a user-friendly, object-oriented and flexible interface.\n\n\nResults\nWith data previously imported into the R or S+ environment, the pROC package builds ROC curves and includes functions for computing confidence intervals, statistical tests for comparing total or partial area under the curve or the operating points of different classifiers, and methods for smoothing ROC curves.\n\n Intermediary and final results are visualised in user-friendly interfaces.\n\n A case study based on published clinical and biomarker data shows how to perform a typical ROC analysis with pROC.\n\n\nConclusions\npROC is a package for R and S+ specifically dedicated to ROC analysis.\n\n It proposes multiple statistical tests to compare ROC curves, and in particular partial areas under the curve, allowing proper ROC interpretation.\n\n pROC is available in two versions: in the R programming language or with a graphical user interface in the S+ statistical software.\n\n It is accessible at http://expasy.\n\norg/tools/pROC/ under the GNU General Public License.\n\n It is also distributed through the CRAN and CSAN public repositories, facilitating its installation.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3068975","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Xavier","surname":"Robin","email":"Xavier.Robin@unige.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Natacha","surname":"Turck","email":"Natacha.Turck@unige.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Alexandre","surname":"Hainard","email":"Alexandre.Hainard@unige.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Natalia","surname":"Tiberti","email":"Natalia.Tiberti@unige.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Frédérique","surname":"Lisacek","email":"Frederique.Lisacek@isb-sib.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jean-Charles","surname":"Sanchez","email":"Jean-Charles.Sanchez@unige.ch","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Markus","surname":"Müller","email":"markus.mueller@isb-sib.ch","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"R 2":[{"doi":"10.5455/aim.2018.26.201-206","date":"2018-08-15","title":"The Use of Telemedicine in Surgical Care: a Systematic Review","abstract":"Introduction:\nTelemedicine describes a healthcare service where physicians communicate with patients remotely using telecommunication technologies.\n\n Telemedicine is being used to provide pre-/postoperative surgical consultation and monitoring as well as surgical education.\n\n\nAim:\nOur purpose was to investigate the broad range of telemedicine technologies used in surgical care.\n\n\nMaterial and methods:\nMEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and Science Direct were searched for available literature from inception to March 30, 2018 with no language restrictions.\n\n The search terms included: cell phones, telemedicine, telecommunications, video, online, videoconferencing, remote consultation, surgery, preoperative, perioperative, postoperative, and surgical procedures.\n\n Studies were included if they used telemedicine in surgery for pre-, peri-, or post-surgery periods, and if they compared traditional surgical care with surgical telemedicine.\n\n We excluded case series, case reports, and conference abstracts from our review.\n\n\nResults:\nA total of 24 studies were included in our review.\n\n The study found that the use of telemedicine in preoperative assessment and diagnosis, evaluation after surgery and follow-up visits to be beneficial.\n\n Patients reported benefits to using telemedicine such as avoiding unnecessary trips to hospitals, saving time and reducing the number of working days missed.\n\n\nConclusion:\nTelemedicine in surgical care can provide benefits to both patients and clinicians.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6195401","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Abdulmajid","surname":"Asiri","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sara","surname":"AlBishi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Wedad","surname":"AlMadani","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ashraf","surname":"ElMetwally","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mowafa","surname":"Househ","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jamcollsurg.2016.01.062","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Current telemedicine for the initial evaluation of general surgery patients in the clinic and hospitalized settings","abstract":"Background\nTelemedicine has had limited implementation for general surgery.\n\n The purpose of this study was to evaluate telemedicine for the initial evaluation of patients in the clinic and hospital settings.\n\n\nMethods\nSynchronous telemedicine consults were conducted by a single surgeon to a rural hospital and clinic.\n\n Reasons for consult, adequacy of consult, days saved by telemedicine consult compared to standard practice, correlation of telemedicine and in-person physical exam, and number of patients who required procedures were evaluated.\n\n\nResults\nOn average, patients were evaluated 7.4?days more rapidly than if the consult had been done by our standard practice.\n\n Telemedicine was adequate for all patients in this study.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis is the first study using telemedicine for the initial consult of general surgery patients in the hospitalized and clinic setting in North America.\n\n The physical exam remains an important component of the general surgery evaluation, and special attention must be considered when structuring the telemedicine program.\n\n Telemedicine is an effective and expedient way to provide consultation for general surgery patients.\n\n Further study is needed to determine which general surgery issues are not amendable to telemedicine consultation, and to determine other surgical specialties that could utilize telemedicine in their Africa","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pntd.0003567","date":"2015-01-26","title":"Social Pathways for Ebola Virus Disease in Rural Sierra Leone, and Some Implications for Containment","abstract":"The current outbreak of Ebola Virus Disease in Upper West Africa is the largest ever recorded.\n Molecular evidence suggests spread has been almost exclusively through human-to-human contact.\n Social factors are thus clearly important to understand the epidemic and ways in which it might be stopped, but these factors have so far been little analyzed.\n The present paper focuses on Sierra Leone, and provides cross sectional data on the least understood part of the epidemicthe largely undocumented spread of Ebola in rural areas.\n Various forms of social networking in rural communities and their relevance for understanding pathways of transmission are described.\n Particular attention is paid to the relationship between marriage, funerals and land tenure.\n Funerals are known to be a high-risk factor for infection.\n It is suggested that more than a shift in awareness of risks will be needed to change local patterns of behavior, especially in regard to funerals, since these are central to the consolidation of community ties.\n A concluding discussion relates the information presented to plans for halting the disease.\n Local consultation and access are seen as major challenges to be addressed.\n","id":"PMC4401769","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Paul","surname":"Richards","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Joseph","surname":"Amara","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mariane 2":[]}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0246454","date":"2021-01-19","title":"Prevalence of depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder in health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic: A systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Objective\nThe COVID-19 pandemic has placed health care workers under psychological stress.\n\n Previous reviews show a high prevalence of mental disorders among health care workers, but these need updating and inclusion of studies written in Chinese.\n\n The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to provide updated prevalence estimates for depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) among health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic, benefitting from the inclusion of studies published in Chinese.\n\n\nMethods\nSystematic search of EMBASE, MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Global Health, Web of Science, CINAHL, Google Scholar and the Chinese databases SinoMed, WanfangMed, CNKI and CQVIP, for studies conducted between December 2019 and August 2020 on the prevalence of depression, anxiety and PTSD in health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n Studies published in both English and Chinese were included.\n\n\nResults\nData on the prevalence of moderate depression, anxiety and PTSD was pooled across 65 studies involving 97,333 health care workers across 21 countries.\n\n The pooled prevalence of depression was 21.7% (95% CI, 18.3%-25.2%), of anxiety 22.1% (95% CI, 18.2%-26.3%), and of PTSD 21.5% (95% CI, 10.5%-34.9%).\n\n Prevalence estimates are also provided for a mild classification of each disorder.\n\n Pooled prevalence estimates of depression and anxiety were highest in studies conducted in the Middle-East (34.6%; 28.9%).\n\n Subgroup and meta-regression analyses were conducted across covariates, including sampling method and outcome measure.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis systematic review and meta-analysis has identified a high prevalence of moderate depression, anxiety and PTSD among health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n Appropriate support is urgently needed.\n\n The response would benefit from additional research on which interventions are effective at mitigating these risks.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7946321","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC_CROSSREF","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Yufei","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"10"},{"firstname":"Nathaniel","surname":"Scherer","email":"NULL","contributions":"10"},{"firstname":"Lambert","surname":"Felix","email":"NULL","contributions":"20"},{"firstname":"Lambert","surname":"Felix","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hannah","surname":"Kuper","email":"NULL","contributions":"20"},{"firstname":"Hannah","surname":"Kuper","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jakob","surname":"Pietschnig","email":"NULL","contributions":"20"},{"firstname":" found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[],"References depth 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30484-9","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Comparing SARS-CoV-2 with SARS-CoV and influenza pandemics","abstract":"The objective of this Personal View is to compare transmissibility, hospitalisation, and mortality rates for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) with those of other epidemic coronaviruses, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), and pandemic influenza viruses.\n The basic reproductive rate (R0) for SARS-CoV-2 is estimated to be 2·5 (range 1·83·6) compared with 2·03·0 for SARS-CoV and the 1918 influenza pandemic, 0·9 for MERS-CoV, and 1·5 for the 2009 influenza pandemic.\n SARS-CoV-2 causes mild or asymptomatic disease in most cases; however, severe to critical illness occurs in a small proportion of infected individuals, with the highest rate seen in people older than 70 years.\n The measured case fatality rate varies between countries, probably because of differences in testing strategies.\n Population-based mortality estimates vary widely across Europe, ranging from zero to high.\n Numbers from the first affected region in Italy, Lombardy, show an all age mortality rate of 154 per 100?000 population.\n Differences are most likely due to varying demographic structures, among other factors.\n However, this new virus has a focal dissemination; therefore, some areas have a higher disease burden and are affected more than others for reasons that are still not understood.\n Nevertheless, early introduction of strict physical distancing and hygiene measures have proven effective in sharply reducing R0 and associated mortality and could in part explain the geographical differences.\n","id":"PMC7333991","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Eskild","surname":"Petersen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marion","surname":"Koopmans","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Unyeong","surname":"Go","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Davidson 2":[{"doi":"10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30484-9","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Comparing SARS-CoV-2 with SARS-CoV and influenza pandemics","abstract":"The objective of this Personal View is to compare transmissibility, hospitalisation, and mortality rates for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) with those of other epidemic coronaviruses, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), and pandemic influenza viruses.\n The basic reproductive rate (R0) for SARS-CoV-2 is estimated to be 2·5 (range 1·83·6) compared with 2·03·0 for SARS-CoV and the 1918 influenza pandemic, 0·9 for MERS-CoV, and 1·5 for the 2009 influenza pandemic.\n SARS-CoV-2 causes mild or asymptomatic disease in most cases; however, severe to critical illness occurs in a small proportion of infected individuals, with the highest rate seen in people older than 70 years.\n The measured case fatality rate varies between countries, probably because of differences in testing strategies.\n Population-based mortality estimates vary widely across Europe, ranging from zero to high.\n Numbers from the first affected region in Italy, Lombardy, show an all age mortality rate of 154 per 100?000 population.\n Differences are most likely due to varying demographic structures, among other factors.\n However, this new virus has a focal dissemination; therefore, some areas have a higher disease burden and are affected more than others for reasons that are still not understood.\n Nevertheless, early introduction of strict physical distancing and hygiene measures have proven effective in sharply reducing R0 and associated mortality and could in part explain the geographical differences.\n","id":"PMC7333991","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Eskild","surname":"Petersen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marion","surname":"Koopmans","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Unyeong","surname":"Go","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Davidson depth 2":[{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(20)30183-5","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Clinical features of patients infected with 2019 novel coronavirus in Wuhan, China","abstract":"Background\nA recent cluster of pneumonia cases in Wuhan, China, was caused by a novel betacoronavirus, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).\n\n We report the epidemiological, clinical, laboratory, and radiological characteristics and treatment and clinical outcomes of these patients.\n\n\nMethods\nAll patients with suspected 2019-nCoV were admitted to a designated hospital in Wuhan.\n\n We prospectively collected and analysed data on patients with laboratory-confirmed 2019-nCoV infection by real-time RT-PCR and next-generation sequencing.\n\n Data were obtained with standardised data collection forms shared by WHO and the International Severe Acute Respiratory and Emerging Infection Consortium from electronic medical records.\n\n Researchers also directly communicated with patients or their families to ascertain epidemiological and symptom data.\n\n Outcomes were also compared between patients who had been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) and those who had not.\n\n\nFindings\nBy Jan 2, 2020, 41 admitted hospital patients had been identified as having laboratory-confirmed 2019-nCoV infection.\n\n Most of the infected patients were men (30 [73%] of 41); less than half had underlying diseases (13 [32%]), including diabetes (eight [20%]), hypertension (six [15%]), and cardiovascular disease (six [15%]).\n\n Median age was 49·0 years (IQR 41·058·0).\n\n 27 (66%) of 41 patients had been exposed to Huanan seafood market.\n\n One family cluster was found.\n\n Common symptoms at onset of illness were fever (40 [98%] of 41 patients), cough (31 [76%]), and myalgia or fatigue (18 [44%]); less common symptoms were sputum production (11 [28%] of 39), headache (three [8%] of 38), haemoptysis (two [5%] of 39), and diarrhoea (one [3%] of 38).\n\n Dyspnoea developed in 22 (55%) of 40 patients (median time from illness onset to dyspnoea 8·0 days [IQR 5·013·0]).\n\n 26 (63%) of 41 patients had lymphopenia.\n\n All 41 patients had pneumonia with abnormal findings on chest CT.\n\n Complications included acute respiratory distress syndrome (12 [29%]), RNAaemia (six [15%]), acute cardiac injury (five [12%]) and secondary infection (four [10%]).\n\n 13 (32%) patients were admitted to an ICU and six (15%) died.\n\n Compared with non-ICU patients, ICU patients had higher plasma levels of IL2, IL7, IL10, GSCF, IP10, MCP1, MIP1A, and TNF?.\n\n\nInterpretation\nThe 2019-nCoV infection caused clusters of severe respiratory illness similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus and was associated with ICU admission and high mortality.\n\n Major gaps in our knowledge of the origin, epidemiology, duration of human transmission, and clinical spectrum of disease need fulfilment by future studies.\n\n\nFunding\nMinistry of Science and Technology, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, National Natural Science Foundation of China, and Beijing Municipal Science and Technology Commission.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7159299","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Chaolin","surname":"Huang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yeming","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xingwang","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lili","surname":"Ren","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jianping","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yi","surname":"Hu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guohui","surname":"Fan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jiuyang","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaoying","surname":"Gu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zhenshun","surname":"Cheng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ting","surname":"Yu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jiaan","surname":"Xia","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuan","surname":"Wei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wenjuan","surname":"Wu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xuelei","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wen","surname":"Yin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hui","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Min","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yan","surname":"Xiao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong","surname":"Gao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Guo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jungang","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guangfa","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rongmeng","surname":"Jiang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zhancheng","surname":"Gao","email":"NULL","contribu Novel Coronavirus from Patients with Pneumonia in China, 2019","abstract":"In December 2019, a cluster of patients with pneumonia of unknown cause was linked to a seafood wholesale market in Wuhan, China.\n A previously unknown betacoronavirus was discovered through the use of unbiased sequencing in samples from patients with pneumonia.\n Human airway epithelial cells were used to isolate a novel coronavirus, named 2019-nCoV, which formed a clade within the subgenus sarbecovirus, Orthocoronavirinae subfamily.\n Different from both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, 2019-nCoV is the seventh member of found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1056/NEJMoa2002032","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Clinical Characteristics of Coronavirus Disease 2019 in China","abstract":"Background\nSince December 2019, when coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) emerged in Wuhan city and rapidly spread throughout China, data have been needed on the clinical characteristics of the affected patients.\n\n\nMethods\nWe extracted data regarding 1099 patients with laboratory-confirmed Covid-19 from 552 hospitals in 30 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China through January 29, 2020. The primary composite end point was admission to an intensive care unit (ICU), the use of mechanical ventilation, or death.\n\n\nResults\nThe median age of the patients was 47 years; 41.9% of the patients were female.\n\n The primary composite end point occurred in 67 patients (6.1%), including 5.0% who were admitted to the ICU, 2.3% who underwent invasive mechanical ventilation, and 1.4% who died.\n\n Only 1.9% of the patients had a history of direct contact with wildlife.\n\n Among nonresidents of Wuhan, 72.3% had contact with residents of Wuhan, including 31.3% who had visited the city.\n\n The most common symptoms were fever (43.8% on admission and 88.7% during hospitalization) and cough (67.8%).\n\n Diarrhea was uncommon (3.8%).\n\n The median incubation period was 4 days (interquartile range, 2 to 7).\n\n On admission, ground-glass opacity was the most common radiologic finding on chest computed tomography (CT) (56.4%).\n\n No radiographic or CT abnormality was found in 157 of 877 patients (17.9%) with nonsevere disease and in 5 of 173 patients (2.9%) with severe disease.\n\n Lymphocytopenia was present in 83.2% of the patients on admission.\n\n\nConclusions\nDuring the first 2 months of the current outbreak, Covid-19 spread rapidly throughout China and caused varying degrees of illness.\n\n Patients often presented without fever, and many did not have abnormal radiologic findings.\n\n (Funded by the National Health Commission of China and existing services are comprehensively reviewed and full use is made of any unrealised potential among healthcare providers.\n Community pharmacy is one of a number of health professions that has a key for the surgical management of gynecological cancers during the COVID-19 pandemic - FRANCOGYN group for the CNGOF<","abstract":"Introduction\nIn the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, specific recommendations are required for the management of patients with gynecologic cancer.\n\n\nMaterials and method\nThe FRANCOGYN group of the National College of French Gynecologists and Obstetricians (CNGOF) convened to develop recommendations based on the consensus conference model.\n\n\nResults\nIf a patient with a gynecologic cancer presents with COVID-19, surgical management should be postponed for at least 15 days.\n\n For cervical cancer, radiotherapy and concomitant radiochemotherapy could replace surgery as first-line treatment and the value of lymph node staging should be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.\n\n For advanced ovarian cancers, neoadjuvant chemotherapy should be preferred over primary cytoreduction surgery.\n\n It is legitimate not to perform hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\n For patients who are scheduled to undergo interval surgery, chemotherapy can be continued and surgery performed after 6 cycles.\n\n For patients with early stage endometrial cancer of low and intermediate preoperative ESMO risk, hysterectomy with bilateral adnexectomy combined with a sentinel lymph node procedure is recommended.\n\n Surgery can be postponed for 12 months in low-risk endometrial cancers (FIGO Ia stage on MRI and grade 12 endometrioid cancer on endometrial biopsy).\n\n For patients of high ESMO risk, the MSKCC algorithm (combining PET-CT and sentinel lymph node biopsy) should be applied to avoid pelvic and lumbar-aortic lymphadenectomy.\n\n\nConclusion\nDuring the COVID-19 pandemic, management of a patient with cancer should be adapted to limit the risks associated with the virus without incurring loss of chance.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7118621","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Cherif","surname":"Akladios","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Henri","surname":"Azais","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Marcos","surname":"Ballester","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sofiane","surname":"Bendifallah","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pierre-Adrien","surname":"Bolze","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Nicolas","surname":"Bourdel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Alexandre","surname":"Bricou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Geoffroy","surname":"Canlorbe","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Xavier","surname":"Carcopino","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pauline","surname":"Chauvet","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pierre","surname":"Collinet","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Charles","surname":"Coutant","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yohann","surname":"Dabi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ludivine","surname":"Dion","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Tristan","surname":"Gauthier","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Olivier","surname":"Graesslin","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Cyrille","surname":"Huchon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Martin","surname":"Koskas","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Frederic","surname":"Kridelka","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Vincent","surname":"Lavoue","email":"Vincent.lavoue@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lise","surname":"Lecointre","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Matthieu","surname":"Mezzadri","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Camille","surname":"Mimoun","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lobna","surname":"Ouldamer","email":"NULL","contrib found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S2468-2667(20)30164-X","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Risk of COVID-19 among front-line health-care workers and the general community: a prospective cohort study","abstract":"Background\nData for front-line health-care workers and risk of COVID-19 are limited.\n\n We sought to assess risk of COVID-19 among front-line health-care workers compared with the general community and the effect of personal protective equipment (PPE) on risk.\n\n\nMethods\nWe did a prospective, observational cohort study in the UK and the USA of the general community, including front-line health-care workers, using self-reported data from the COVID Symptom Study smartphone application (app) from March 24 (UK) and March 29 (USA) to April 23, 2020. Participants were voluntary users of the app and at first use provided information on demographic factors (including age, sex, race or ethnic background, height and weight, and occupation) and medical history, and subsequently reported any COVID-19 symptoms.\n\n We used Cox proportional hazards modelling to estimate multivariate-adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) of our primary outcome, which was a positive COVID-19 test.\n\n The COVID Symptom Study app is registered with ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, NCT04331509.\n\n\nFindings\nAmong 2?035?395 community individuals and 99?795 front-line health-care workers, we recorded 5545 incident reports of a positive COVID-19 test over 34?435?272 person-days.\n\n Compared with the general community, front-line health-care workers were at increased risk for reporting a positive COVID-19 test (adjusted HR 11·61, 95% CI 10·9312·33).\n\n To account for differences in testing frequency between front-line health-care workers and the general community and possible selection bias, an inverse probability-weighted model was used to adjust for the likelihood of receiving a COVID-19 test (adjusted HR 3·40, 95% CI 3·373·43).\n\n Secondary and post-hoc analyses suggested adequacy of PPE, clinical setting, and ethnic background were also important factors.\n\n\nInterpretation\nIn the UK and the USA, risk of reporting a positive test for COVID-19 was increased among front-line health-care workers.\n\n Health-care systems should ensure adequate availability of PPE and develop additional strategies to protect health-care workers from COVID-19, particularly those from Black, Asian, and minority ethnic backgrounds.\n\n Additional follow-up of these observational findings is needed.\n\n\nFunding\nZoe Global, Wellcome Trust, Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, National Institutes of Health Research, UK Research and Innovation, Alzheimer's Society, National Institutes of Health, National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, and Massachusetts Consortium on Pathogen Readiness.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7491202","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Long Mediator between Work-Related Stressors and Health Outcomes","abstract":"It is currently unknown if unfavorable working conditions, reflected by the demandcontrolsupport model and the effortreward imbalance model, directly influence health or if the effects may be mediated by work-related attitudes and behaviors such as workaholism.\n In the present study, 988 employees (55.6% males, mean age 36.09, SD = 9.23) from a large consultant firm participated in a cross-sectional survey assessing work variables such as job demands, job control, social support, effort, reward, and overcommitment.\n Workaholism was also assessed together with eight different health-related outcomes.\n Although direct effects of the work stressors on health were found on most health outcomes, the work-related stressors were overall strongly related to workaholism (R2 = 0.522), which, in turn, was positively related to four (anxiety/insomnia, somatic symptoms, emotional exhaustion, and social dysfunction) of the eight outcome variables.\n Of a total of 40 relationships between work-related stressors and health outcomes, workaholism fully mediated three of these, and partly mediated 12. Overall, the study suggests that the effects of work-related stressors on health in many cases may be mediated by workaholism.\n","id":"PMC5800172","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Cecilie found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12888-018-1589-y","date":"2018-01-02","title":"Subtypes in clinical burnout patients enrolled in an employee rehabilitation program: differences in burnout profiles, depression, and recovery/resources-stress balance","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Burnout is generally perceived a unified disorder with homogeneous symptomatology across people (exhaustion, cynicism, and reduced professional efficacy).\n\n However, increasing evidence points to intra-individual patterns of burnout symptoms in non-clinical samples such as students, athletes, healthy, and burned-out employees.\n\n Different burnout subtypes might therefore exist.\n\n Yet, burnout subtypes based on burnout profiles have hardly been explored in clinical patients, and the samples investigated in previous studies were rather heterogeneous including patients with various physical, psychological, and social limitations, symptoms, and disabilities.\n\n Therefore, the aim of this study is to explore burnout subtypes based on burnout profiles in clinically diagnosed burnout patients enrolled in an employee rehabilitation program, and to investigate whether the subtypes differ in depression, recovery/resources-stress balance, and sociodemographic characteristics.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>One hundred three patients (66 women, 37 men) with a clinical burnout diagnosis, who were enrolled in a 5 week employee rehabilitation program in two specialized psychosomatic clinics in Austria, completed a series of questionnaires including the Maslach Burnout Inventory  General Survey (MBI-GS), the Beck Depression Inventory, and the Recovery-Stress-Questionnaire for Work.\n\n Cluster analyses with the three MBI-GS subscales as clustering variables were used to identify the burnout subtypes.\n\n Subsequent multivariate/univariate analysis of variance and Pearson chi-square tests were performed to investigate differences in depression, recovery/resources-stress balance, and sociodemographic characteristics.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Three different burnout subtypes were discovered: the exhausted subtype, the exhausted/cynical subtype, and the burned-out subtype.\n\n The burned-out subtype and the exhausted/cynical subtype showed both more severe depression symptoms and a worse recovery/resources-stress balance than the exhausted subtype.\n\n Furthermore, the burned-out subtype was more depressed than the exhausted/cynical subtype, but no difference was observed between these two subtypes with regard to perceived stress, recovery, and resources.\n\n Sociodemographic characteristics were not associated with the subtypes.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>The present study indicates that there are different subtypes in clinical burnout patients (exhausted, exhausted/cynical, and burned-out), which might represent patients at different developmental stages in the burnout cycle.\n\n Future studies need to replicate the current findings, investigate the stability of the symptom patterns, and examine the efficacy of rehabilitation interventions in different subtypes.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5773035","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Kathrin","surname":"Bauernhofer","email":"kathrin.bauernhofer@uni-graz.at","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Daniela","surname":"Bassa","email":"daniela.bassa@edu.uni-graz.at","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Daniela","surname":"Bassa","email":"daniela.bassa@edu.uni-graz.at","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Markus","surname":"Canazei","email":"markus.canazei@bartenbach.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Paulino","surname":"Jiménez","email":"paul.jimenez@uni-graz.at","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Manuela","surname":"Paechter","email":"manuela.paechter@uni-graz.at","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ilona","surname":"Papousek","email":"ilona.papousek@uni-graz.at","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Andreas","surname":"Fink","email":"andreas.fink@uni-graz.at","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elisabeth Depression, and Borderline Personality: A 1,163-Participant Study","abstract":"We examined the association of burnout with borderline personality (BP) traits in a study of 1,163 educational staff (80.9% women; mean age: 42.96).\n Because burnout has been found to overlap with depression, parallel analyses of burnout and depression were conducted.\n Burnout symptoms were assessed with the Shirom-Melamed Burnout Measure, depressive symptoms with the PHQ-9, and BP traits with the Borderline Personality Questionnaire.\n Burnout was found to be associated with BP traits, controlling for neuroticism and history of depressive disorders.\n In women, burnout was linked to both the affective insecurity and the impulsiveness component of BP.\n In men, only the link between burnout and affective insecurity reached statistical significance.\n Compared to participants with low BP scores, participants with high BP scores reported more burnout symptoms, depressive symptoms, neuroticism, and occupational stress and less satisfaction with life.\n Disattenuated correlations between burnout and depression were close to 1, among both women (0.91) and men (0.94).\n The patterns of association of burnout and depression with the main study variables were similar, pointing to overlapping nomological networks.\n Burnout symptoms were only partly attributed to work by our participants.\n Our findings suggest that burnout is associated with BP traits through burnout-depression overlap.\n","id":"PMC5769336","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Renzo","surname":"Bianchi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jean-Pierre","surname":"Rolland","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jesús Anxiety Symptoms and Occupational Stress among Community Healthcare Workers in China: A Cross-Sectional Study","abstract":"Background\nSeveral occupational stress studies of healthcare workers have predicted a high prevalence of anxiety symptoms, which can affect their quality of life and the care that they provide.\n\n However, few studies have been conducted among community healthcare workers in China.\n\n We attempted to explore whether burnout mediates the association between occupational stress and anxiety symptoms.\n\n\nMethods\nA cross-sectional survey was completed in Liaoning Province, China from November to December 2012. A total of 1,752 healthcare workers from 52 Community Health Centers participated in this study, and all participants were given self-administered questionnaires.\n\n These questionnaires addressed the following aspects: the Zung Self-Rating Anxiety Scale, the Chinese version of the effort-reward imbalance scale and the Maslach Burnout InventoryGeneral Survey.\n\n Finally, the study included 1,243 effective respondents (effective response rate, 70.95%).\n\n Hierarchical linear regression analysis, performed with SPSS 17.0, was used to estimate the effect of burnout.\n\n\nResults\nThe prevalence of anxiety symptoms among the community healthcare workers was 38.0%.\n\n After adjusting for demographic characteristics, the effortreward ratio and overcommitment positively predicted anxiety symptoms.\n\n Meanwhile, the effortreward ratio and overcommitment were positively related to the emotional exhaustion and cynicism subscales of burnout.\n\n In addition, the emotional exhaustion and cynicism subscales were positively related to anxiety symptoms.\n\n Thus, there is a link between burnout, occupational stress and anxiety symptoms.\n\n\nConclusions\nBurnout mediates the effect of occupational stress on anxiety symptoms.\n\n To effectively reduce the impact of occupational stress on anxiety symptoms, burnout management should be considered.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4161428","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Yanwei","surname":"Ding","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jianwei","surname":"Qu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Xiaosong","surname":"Yu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Shuang","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Soraya","surname":"Seedat","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Soraya","surname":"Seedat","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jad.2018.02.090","date":"1970-01-01","title":"12-month mental health problems, such as secondary traumatic stress, burnout, anxiety, and depression.\n However, so far, the exact nature of these work-related stressors (traumatic vs.\n non-traumatic stressors) has not been investigated.\n This concurrent triangulation mixed methods cross-sectional study aimed to compare mental health symptoms in hospital midwives and NICU nurses, and to identify and compare work-related traumatic and non-traumatic stressors for both professional groups.\n 122 midwives and 91 NICU nurses of two Swiss university hospitals completed quantitative measures (Secondary Traumatic Stress Scale, STSS; Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, HADS; Maslach Burnout Inventory, MBI) and one qualitative question in an online survey.\n When controlling for socio-demographic variables, NICU nurses had a higher STSS total score and higher STSS subscales scores and less HADS anxiety subscale scores than hospital midwives.\n Work-related stressors were classified into five themes: Working environment, Nursing/midwifery care, Dealing with death and dying, Case management and Others.\n Forty-six (46.3%) percent of these were classified as traumatic work-related stressors.\n NICU nurses reported more traumatic stressors in their working environment but no other differences between professional groups regarding the total number of work-related traumatic vs.\n non-traumatic stressors were found.\n Measures, such as teaching strategies to amend the subjective appraisal of the traumatic stressors or providing time to recover in-between frequently occurring work-related traumatic stressors might not only improve the mental health of professionals but also decrease sick leave and improve the quality of patient found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0201856","date":"2018-07-23","title":"Populating the Data Ark: An attempt to retrieve, preserve, and liberate data from the most highly-cited psychology and psychiatry articles","abstract":"The vast majority of scientific articles published to-date have not been accompanied by concomitant publication of the underlying research data upon which they are based.\n This state of affairs precludes the routine re-use and re-analysis of research data, undermining the efficiency of the scientific enterprise, and compromising the credibility of claims that cannot be independently verified.\n It may be especially important to make data available for the most influential studies that have provided a foundation for subsequent research and theory development.\n Therefore, we launched an initiativethe Data Arkto examine whether we could retrospectively enhance the preservation and accessibility of important scientific data.\n Here we report the outcome of our efforts to retrieve, preserve, and liberate data from 111 of the most highly-cited articles published in psychology and psychiatry between 20062011 (n = 48) and 20142016 (n = 63).\n Most data sets were not made available (76/111, 68%, 95% CI [60, 77]), some were only made available with restrictions (20/111, 18%, 95% CI [10, 27]), and few were made available in a completely unrestricted form (15/111, 14%, 95% CI [5, 22]).\n Where extant data sharing systems were in place, they usually (17/22, 77%, 95% CI [54, 91]) did not allow unrestricted access.\n Authors reported several barriers to data sharing, including issues related to data ownership and ethical concerns.\n The Data Ark initiative could help preserve and liberate important scientific data, surface barriers to data sharing, and advance community discussions on data stewardship.\n","id":"PMC6072126","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Tom E.","surname":"Hardwicke","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"John P. JPMA","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3238/arztebl.2011.0781","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Burnout: a fashionable diagnosis","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1080/09720073.2015.11891702","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Level of Anxiety and Burnout among Martial Athletes into 17th Mediterranean Games","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.childyouth.2014.09.015","date":"1970-01-01","title":"A meta-analysis of turnover intention predictors among US child welfare workers","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3205/hta000087","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Differential diagnostic of the burnout syndrome","abstract":"Introduction \nThere is no consistent definition of burnout.\n\n It is neither a defined diagnosis in ICD-10 nor in DSM-IV.\n\n Yet it is diagnosed by office-based doctors and clinicians.\n\n Mainly due to reimbursement reasons, diagnoses like depression are used instead of burnout diagnoses.\n\n Therefore burnout has a very high individual, social and economic impact.\n\n\nObjectives \n\n\n\nHow is burnout diagnosed? Which criteria are relevant? How valid and reliable are the used tools?\nMethods \nBased on a systematic literature research in 36 databases, studies in English or German language, published since 2004, concerning medical and differential diagnoses, economic impact and ethical aspects of burnout, are included and evaluated.\n\n\nResults \n852 studies are identified.\n\n After considering the inclusion and exclusion criteria and after reviewing the full texts, 25 medical and one ethical study are included.\n\n No economic study met the criteria.\n\n\nDiscussion \nThe evidence of the majority of the studies is predominantly low.\n\n Most of the studies are descriptive and explorative.\n\n Self-assessment tools are mainly used, overall the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI).\n\n Objective data like medical parameters, health status, sick notes or judgements by third persons are extremely seldomly included in the studies.\n\n The sample construction is coincidental in the majority of cases, response rates are often low.\n\n Almost no longitudinal studies are available.\n\n There are insufficient results on the stability and the duration of related symptoms.\n\n The ambiguity of the burnout diagnosis is regularly neglected in the studies.\n\n\nConclusions \nThe authors conclude, that (1) further research, particularly high-quality studies are needed, to broaden the understanding of the burnout syndrome.\n\n Equally (2) a definition of the burnout syndrome has to be found which goes beyond the published understanding of burnout and is based on common scientific consent.\n\n Furthermore, there is a need (3) for finding a standardized, international accepted and valid procedure for the differentiated diagnostics of burnout and for (4) developing a third party assessment tool for the diagnosis of burnout.\n\n Finally, (5) the economic effects and implication of burnout diagnostics on the economy, the health insurances and the patients have to be analysed.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3010892","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Dieter","surname":"Korczak","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Beate","surname":"Huber","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Christine","surname":"Kister","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1046/j.1525-1497.2001.016009606.x","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpsyt.2015.00113","date":"2015-07-27","title":"Differentiating Burnout from Depression: Personality Matters!","abstract":"Stress-related affective disorders have been identified as a core health problem of the twenty-first century.\n In the endeavor to identify vulnerability factors, personality has been discussed as a major factor explaining and predicting disorders like depression or burnout.\n An unsolved question is whether there are specific personality factors allowing differentiation of burnout from depression.\n The present study tested the relation between one of the most prominent, biological personality theories, Cloningers Temperament and Character Inventory, and common measures of burnout (Maslach Burnout Inventory General) and depression (Beck Depression Inventory 2) in a sample of German employees (N?=?944) and a sample of inpatients (N?=?425).\n Although the same personality traits (harm avoidance and self-directedness) were predominantly associated with burnout and depression, there was a much stronger association to depression than to burnout in both samples.\n Besides, we observed specific associations between personality traits and subcomponents of burnout.\n Our results underline differences in the association of burnout vs.\n depression to personality, which may mirror differences in scope.\n While symptoms of depression affect all aspects of life, burnout is supposed to be specifically related to the workplace and its requirements.\n The much stronger association of personality to depression can be important to select appropriate therapy methods and to develop a more specified treatment for burnout in comparison to depression.\n","id":"PMC4534781","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Martin Christoph","surname":"Melchers","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Thomas","surname":"Plieger","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Rolf","surname":"Meermann","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Martin","surname":"Reuter","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0190607","date":"2017-12-18","title":"Sleep and biological parameters in professional burnout: A psychophysiological characterization","abstract":"Professional burnout syndrome has been described in association with insomnia and metabolic, inflammatory and immune correlates.\n We investigated the interest of exploring biological parameters and sleep disturbances in relation to burnout symptoms among white-collar workers.\n Fifty-four participants with burnout were compared to 86 healthy control participants in terms of professional rank level, sleep, job strain (Karasek questionnaire), social support, anxiety and depression (HAD scale).\n Fasting concentrations of glycaemia, glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1C), total-cholesterol, triglycerides, C-reactive protein (CRP), thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D), and white blood cell (WBC) counts were assessed.\n Analysis of variance and a forward Stepwise Multiple Logistic Regression were made to identify predictive factors of burnout.\n Besides reporting more job strain (in particular job control p = 0.02), higher levels of anxiety (p&lt;0.001), and sleep disorders related to insomnia (OR = 21.5, 95%CI = 8.852.3), participants with burnout presented higher levels of HbA1C, glycaemia, CRP, lower levels of 25(OH)D, higher number of leukocytes, neutrophils and monocytes (P&lt;0.001 for all) and higher total-cholesterol (P = 0.01).\n In particular, when HbA1c is &gt; 3.5%, the prevalence of burnout increases from 16.6% to 60.0% (OR = 4.3, 95%CI = 2.86.9).\n Strong significant positive correlation existed between HbA1C and the two dimensions (emotional exhaustion and depersonalization (r = 0.79 and r = 0.71, p&lt;0.01)) of burnout.\n Models including job strain, job satisfaction, anxiety and insomnia did not predict burnout (p = 0.30 and p = 0.50).\n However, when HbA1C levels is included, the prediction of burnout became significant (P = 0.03).\n Our findings demonstrated the interest of sleep and biological parameters, in particular HbA1C levels, in the characterization of professional burnout.\n","id":"PMC5791983","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Arnaud","surname":"Metlaine","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Fabien","surname":"Sauvet","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Fabien","surname":"Sauvet","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Danielle","surname":"Gomez-Merino","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Thierry","surname":"Boucher","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maxime","surname":"Elbaz","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jean found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0185781","date":"2017-09-19","title":"Physical, psychological and occupational consequences of job burnout: A systematic review of prospective studies","abstract":"Burnout is a syndrome that results from chronic stress at work, with several consequences to workers well-being and health.\n This systematic review aimed to summarize the evidence of the physical, psychological and occupational consequences of job burnout in prospective studies.\n The PubMed, Science Direct, PsycInfo, SciELO, LILACS and Web of Science databases were searched without language or date restrictions.\n The Transparent Reporting of Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses guidelines were followed.\n Prospective studies that analyzed burnout as the exposure condition were included.\n Among the 993 articles initially identified, 61 fulfilled the inclusion criteria, and 36 were analyzed because they met three criteria that must be followed in prospective studies.\n Burnout was a significant predictor of the following physical consequences: hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, coronary heart disease, hospitalization due to cardiovascular disorder, musculoskeletal pain, changes in pain experiences, prolonged fatigue, headaches, gastrointestinal issues, respiratory problems, severe injuries and mortality below the age of 45 years.\n The psychological effects were insomnia, depressive symptoms, use of psychotropic and antidepressant medications, hospitalization for mental disorders and psychological ill-health symptoms.\n Job dissatisfaction, absenteeism, new disability pension, job demands, job resources and presenteeism were identified as professional outcomes.\n Conflicting findings were observed.\n In conclusion, several prospective and high-quality studies showed physical, psychological and occupational consequences of job burnout.\n The individual and social impacts of burnout highlight the need for preventive interventions and early identification of this health condition in the work environment.\n","id":"PMC5627926","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Denise Albieri controlled intervention of workplace-based group cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia","abstract":"Purpose\nSleep disturbance is common in the working population, often associated with work stress, health complaints and impaired work performance.\n\n This study evaluated a group intervention at work, based on cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia, and the moderating effects of burnout scores at baseline.\n\n\nMethods\nThis is a randomized controlled intervention with a waiting list control group.\n\n Participants were employees working at least 75% of full time, reporting self-perceived regular sleep problems.\n\n Data were collected at baseline, post-intervention and at a 3-month follow-up through diaries, wrist-actigraphy and questionnaires including the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) and the ShiromMelamed Burnout Questionnaire (SMBQ).\n\n Fifty-one participants (63% women) completed data collections.\n\n\nResults\nA multilevel mixed model showed no significant differences between groups for sleep over time, while there was a significant effect on insomnia symptoms when excluding participants working shifts (N?=?11) from the analysis (p?=?0.044).\n\n Moreover, a moderating effect of baseline-levels of burnout scores was observed on insomnia symptoms (p?=?0.009).\n\n A post-hoc analysis showed that individuals in the intervention group with low burnout scores at baseline (SMBQ?&lt;?3.75) displayed significantly reduced ISI scores at follow-up, compared to individuals with high burnout scores at baseline (p?=?0.005).\n\n\nConclusions\nGroup CBT for insomnia given at the workplace did not reduce sleep problems looking at the group as a whole, while it was indicated that the intervention reduced insomnia in employees with regular daytime work.\n\n The results also suggest that workplace-based group CBT may improve sleep in employees with primary insomnia if not concomitant with high burnout scores.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (10.1007/s00420-018-1291-x) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5908834","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Helena","surname":"Schiller","email":"helena.schiller@su.se","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Marie","surname":"Söderström","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Marie","surname":"Söderström","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mats","surname":"Lekander","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kristiina","surname":"Rajaleid","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Göran","surname":"Kecklund","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1348/000711007X255327","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Fixed-versus incivility against new nurses on job burn-out: a cross-sectional study in China","abstract":"Abstract\nThis study had three objectives: (1) to investigate the impact of workplace incivility on job burn-out of new nursing staff, (2) to verify the partial mediating role of anxiety in the relationship between workplace incivility and job burn-out, (3) to examine the resilience moderating the relations between workplace incivility and job burn-out.\n\n\nDesign\nA cross-sectional online survey was conducted in May 2016 in China.\n\n\nSetting\nThe survey was conducted in 54 cities across 29 provinces of China.\n\n\nParticipants\nA total of 903 participants were invited.\n\n Ultimately, 696 new nurses (&lt;3?service years) completed valid questionnaires.\n\n The effective response rate was 77.1%.\n\n Entry criteria: voluntary participation, having less than three service years and being a registered nurse.\n\n Exclusion criteria: being an irregular nurse, having more than three service years and refusing to participate in this work.\n\n\nOutcome measures\nAn anonymous questionnaire was distributed among new nurses.\n\n The relationships and mechanism among the variables were explored using descriptive statistical analysis, Pearsons correlation coefficient and multiple linear regression analysis.\n\n\nResults\nThe findings showed that workplace incivility was positively correlated with anxiety (r=0.371, p&lt;0.01) and job burn-out (r=0.238, p&lt;0.01) of new nurses.\n\n The positive relation between anxiety (?=0.364, p&lt;0.01) and job burn-out (?=0.240, p&lt;0.01) was also significant.\n\n Moreover, anxiety partially mediated (z=7.807, p&lt;0.01) and resilience moderated (?=?0.564, p&lt;0.01) the association between workplace incivility and job burn-out.\n\n\nConclusion\nExperience of workplace incivility by new nurses would likely generate anxiety in the victims.\n\n Further, the increased anxiety state could elevate their level of job burn-out.\n\n New nurses with high levels of resilience could buffer the negative influence of workplace incivility by using a positive coping demonstrated sufficient sensitivity to detect expected effects of a two-point (range 840) change in sleep-related impairment.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>PFI scales have good performance Behavior Among Mental Health Care Professionals?","abstract":"Aim:\nThis study aims to examine the possible relation between depression and burnout as predictors to aggressive behaviors among mental healthcare professionals.\n\n\nMethods:\nFor the purposes of this study 72 mental health care professionals were recruited and were evaluated in three questionnaires which were provided to them online.\n\n Firstly regarding depression, the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) was administered, secondly, concerning burnout, Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI) was applied and finally, regarding aggression, the Aggression Questionnaire (GAQ) was employed.\n\n Statistical data analysis was performed using the IBM SPSS Statistics Version 19. The level of statistical significance was set at up at 0.05.\nResults:\nThe results showed that depression is considered to be a statistically significant predictor of aggressive behaviors.\n\n However, burnout was not found to be a statistically significant predictor of aggression.\n\n In addition, a statistically significant relationship was found between burnout and depression.\n\n\nConclusions:\nIt seems to be of essential importance for mental healthcare professionals to be provided with support and assistance in order to diminish the potential high-stress settings.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6195016","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Aspasia","surname":"Tzeletopoulou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Victoria","surname":"Alikari","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sofia","surname":"Zyga","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maria","surname":"Tsironi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maria","surname":"Lavdaniti","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Paraskevi","surname":"Theofilou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpsyg.2016.00090","date":"2016-01-15","title":"Subgroup Analysis in Burnout: Relations Between Fatigue, Anxiety, and Depression","abstract":"Several authors have suggested that burned out patients do not form a homogeneous group and that subgroups should be considered.\n The identification of these subgroups may contribute to a better understanding of the burnout construct and lead to more specific therapeutic interventions.\n Subgroup analysis may also help clarify whether burnout is a distinct entity and whether subgroups of burnout overlap with other disorders such as depression and chronic fatigue syndrome.\n In a group of 113 clinically diagnosed burned out patients, levels of fatigue, depression, and anxiety were assessed.\n In order to identify possible subgroups, we performed a two-step cluster analysis.\n The analysis revealed two clusters that differed from one another in terms of symptom severity on the three aforementioned measures.\n Depression appeared to be the strongest predictor of group membership.\n These results are considered in the light of the scientific debate on whether burnout can be distinguished from depression and whether burnout subtyping is useful.\n Finally, implications for clinical practice and future research are discussed.\n","id":"PMC4740380","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Arno","surname":"van
