found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjgh-2017-000471","date":"2017-11-08","title":"Impact of Ebola experiences and risk perceptions on mental health in Sierra Leone, July 2015","abstract":"Background\nThe mental health impact of the 20142016 Ebola epidemic has been described among survivors, family members and healthcare workers, but little is known about its impact on the general population of affected countries.\n\n We assessed symptoms of anxiety, depression and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in the general population in Sierra Leone after over a year of outbreak response.\n\n\nMethods\nWe administered a cross-sectional survey in July 2015 to a national sample of 3564 consenting participants selected through multistaged cluster sampling.\n\n Symptoms of anxiety and depression were measured by Patient Health Questionnaire-4. PTSD symptoms were measured by six items from the Impact of Events Scale-revised.\n\n Relationships among Ebola experience, perceived Ebola threat and mental health symptoms were examined through binary logistic regression.\n\n\nResults\nPrevalence of any anxiety-depression symptom was 48% (95% CI 46.8% to 50.0%), and of any PTSD symptom 76% (95% CI 75.0% to 77.8%).\n\n In addition, 6% (95% CI 5.4% to 7.0%) met the clinical cut-off for anxiety-depression, 27% (95% CI 25.8% to 28.8%) met levels of clinical concern for PTSD and 16% (95% CI 14.7% to 17.1%) met levels of probable PTSD diagnosis.\n\n Factors associated with higher reporting of any symptoms in bivariate analysis included region of residence, experiences with Ebola and perceived Ebola threat.\n\n Knowing someone quarantined for Ebola was independently associated with anxiety-depression (adjusted OR (AOR) 2.3, 95%?CI 1.7 to 2.9) and PTSD (AOR 2.095% CI 1.5 to 2.8) symptoms.\n\n Perceiving Ebola as a threat was independently associated with anxiety-depression (AOR 1.69 95% CI 1.44 to 1.98) and PTSD (AOR 1.86 95% CI 1.56 to 2.21) symptoms.\n\n\nConclusion\nSymptoms of PTSD and anxiety-depression were common after one year of Ebola response; psychosocial support may be needed for people with Ebola-related experiences.\n\n Preventing, detecting, and responding to mental health conditions should be an important component of global health security efforts.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5873549","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mohamed Staff Involved in the 2019 Novel Coronavirus Disease Outbreak","abstract":"Objective\nThe outbreak of the 2019 novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) not only caused particularly large public health problems, but also caused great psychological distress, especially for medical staff.\n\n We aimed to investigate the prevalence rate of insomnia and to confirm the related social psychological factors among medical staff in hospitals during the COVID-19 outbreak.\n\n\nMethod\nMedical staff members in China were recruited, including frontline medical workers.\n\n The questionnaire, administered through the WeChat program, obtained demographic data and asked self-design questions related to the COVID-19 outbreak, insomnia/depressive/anxiety symptoms, and stress-related symptoms.\n\n We used a logistic regression analysis to examine the associations between sociodemographic factors and insomnia symptoms.\n\n\nResult\nThere were a total of 1,563 participants in our study.\n\n Five-hundred-and-sixty-four (36.1%) participants had insomnia symptoms according to the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) (total score ? 8).\n\n A multiple binary logistic regression model revealed that insomnia symptoms were associated with an education level of high school or below (OR = 2.69, p = 0.042, 95% CI = 1.07.0), being a doctor (OR = 0.44, p = 0.007, 95% CI = 0.20.8), currently working in an isolation unit (OR = 1.71, p = 0.038, 95% CI = 1.02.8), is worried about being infected (OR = 2.30, p &lt; 0.001, 95% CI = 1.63.4), perceived lack of helpfulness in terms of psychological support from news or social media with regard to COVID-19 (OR = 2.10, p = 0.001, 95% CI = 1.33.3), and having very strong uncertainty regarding effective disease control (OR = 3.30, p = 0.013, 95% CI = 1.38.5).\n\n\nConclusion\nOur study found that more than one-third of the medical staff suffered insomnia symptoms during the COVID-19 outbreak.\n\n The related factors included education level, an isolation environment, psychological worries about the COVID-19 outbreak, and being a doctor.\n\n Interventions for insomnia among medical staff are needed considering the various sociopsychological factors at play in this found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.socscimed.2005.04.010","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The experience of SARS-related stigma at Amoy Gardens","abstract":"Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) possesses characteristics that render it particularly prone to stigmatization.\n SARS-related stigma, despite its salience for public health and stigma research, has had little examination.\n This study combines survey and case study methods to examine subjective stigma among residents of Amoy Gardens (AG), the first officially recognized site of community outbreak of SARS in Hong Kong.\n A total of 903 residents of AG completed a self-report questionnaire derived from two focus groups conducted toward the end of the 3-month outbreak.\n Case studies of two residents who lived in Block E, the heart of the SARS epidemic at AG, complement the survey data.\n Findings show that stigma affected most residents and took various forms of being shunned, insulted, marginalized, and rejected in the domains of work, interpersonal relationships, use of services and schooling.\n Stigma was also associated with psychosomatic distress.\n Residents strategies for diminishing stigma varied with gender, age, education, occupation, and proximity to perceived risk factors for SARS such as residential location, previous SARS infection and the presence of ex-SARS household members.\n Residents attributed stigma to government mismanagement, contagiousness of the mysterious SARS virus, and alarmist media reporting.\n Stigma clearly decreased, but never completely disappeared, after the outbreak.\n The findings confirm and add to existing knowledge on the varied origins, correlates, and impacts of stigma.\n They also highlight the synergistic roles of inconsistent health policy responses and risk miscommunication by the media in rapidly amplifying stigma toward an unfamiliar illness.\n While recognizing the intrinsically stigmatizing nature of public health measures to control SARS, we recommend that a consistent inter-sectoral approach is needed to minimize stigma and to make an effective health response to future outbreaks.\n","id":"PMC7116975","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sing","surname":"Lee","email":"singlee@cuhk.edu.hk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lydia of psychiatric morbidity and psychological adaptation of the nurses in a structured SARS caring unit during outbreak: A prospective and periodic assessment study in Taiwan","abstract":"To assess the rapidly changing psychological status of nurses during the acute phase of the 2003 SARS outbreak, we conducted a prospective and periodic evaluation of psychiatric morbidity and psychological adaptation among nurses in SARS units and non-SARS units.\n Nurse participants were from two SARS units (regular SARS [N = 44] and SARS ICU [N = 26]) and two non-SARS units (Neurology [N = 15] and CCU [N = 17]).\n Participants periodically self-evaluated their depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress symptoms, sleep disturbance, attitude towards SARS and family support.\n Results showed that depression (38.5% vs.\n 3.1%) and insomnia (37% vs.\n 9.7%) were, respectively, greater in the SARS unit nurses than the non-SARS unit nurses.\n No difference between these two groups was found in the prevalence of post-traumatic stress symptoms (33% vs.\n 18.7%), yet, three unit subjects (SARS ICU, SARS regular and Neurology) had significantly higher rate than those in CCU (29.7% vs.\n 11.8%, respectively) (p &lt; 0.05).\n For the SARS unit nurses, significant reduction in mood ratings, insomnia rate and perceived negative feelings as well as increasing knowledge and understanding of SARS at the end of the study (all p &lt; 0.001) indicated that a gradual psychological adaptation had occurred.\n The adjustment of nurses in the more structured SARS ICU environment, where nurses care for even more severely ill patients, may have been as good or better than that of nurses in the regular SARS unit.\n Occurrence of psychiatric symptoms was linked to direct exposure to SARS patient care, previous mood disorder history, younger age and perceived negative feelings.\n Positive coping attitude and strong social and family support may have protected against acute stress.\n In conclusion, the psychological impact on the caring staffs facing future bio-disaster will be minimized with lowered risk factors and a safer and more structured work severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) nursing staff experienced before and after a SARS prevention program.\n The 116 subjects were recruited from nursing staff in the largest obligatory SARS found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.ijnurstu.2006.02.012","date":"2006-02-28","title":"The relevance of psychosocial variables and working conditions in predicting nurses coping strategies during the SARS crisis: An online questionnaire survey","abstract":"Objectives\nThe purpose of this investigation was to examine the relationship between psychosocial variables and working conditions, and nurses coping methods and distress in response to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) crisis in Canada.\n\n\nParticipants and procedure\nThe sample consisted of 333 nurses (315 women, 18 men) who completed an Internet-mediated questionnaire that was posted on the Registered Nurses Association of Ontario (RNAO) website between March and May 2004. The questionnaire was restricted to respondents who had to authenticate their RNAO membership with a valid username and password before accessing the questionnaire.\n\n This served a dual purpose: to ensure that only RNAO nurses completed the questionnaire and thereby safeguarding the generalizability of the findings; and second, to prevent any one nurse from contributing more than once to the overall sample.\n\n\nResults\nCorrelational analysis yielded several significant relationships between psychosocial variables and working conditions, and the traditional correlates of burnout and stress.\n\n Three multiple regression analysis revealed that the model we evolvedincluding higher levels of vigor, organizational support, and trust in equipment/infection control initiative; and lower levels of contact with SARS patients, and time spent in quarantinepredicted to lower levels of avoidance behavior, emotional exhaustion, and state anger.\n\n\nConclusions\nBy employing models of stress and burnout that combine psychosocial variables and working conditions, researchers can account for significant amounts of variance in outcomes related to burnout.\n\n These findings highlight the importance of vigor and perceived organizational support in predicting nurses symptoms of burnout.\n\n For healthcare administrators, this means that a likely strategy for assuaging the negative outcomes of stress should address nurses psychosocial concerns and the working conditions that they face during novel times of crisis.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7094220","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Zdravko","surname":"Marjanovic","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Esther found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jpsychores.2007.07.015","date":"2007-07-31","title":"Impact on health care workers employed in high-risk areas during the Toronto SARS outbreak","abstract":"Background\nA number of publications focusing on health care workers (HCWs) during a severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak have suggested that HCWs experienced psychological distress, particularly increased levels of posttraumatic stress symptomatology (PTSS).\n\n Factors contributing to increased distress in HCWs working in high-risk areas treating patients with SARS have not been fully elucidated.\n\n The goal of this study was to quantify the psychological effects of working in a high-risk unit during the SARS outbreak.\n\n\nMethods\nHCWs in a Toronto hospital who worked in high-risk areas completed a questionnaire regarding their attitude toward the SARS crisis along with the Impact of Event ScaleRevised, which screens for PTSS.\n\n The comparison group consisted of clinical units that had no contact with patients infected with SARS.\n\n\nResults\nFactors that were identified to cause distress in the 248 respondent HCWs were the following: (a) perception of risk to themselves, (b) impact of the SARS crisis on their work life, (c) depressive affect, and (d) working in a high-risk unit.\n\n In addition, HCWs who cared for only one SARS patient in comparison to those caring for multiple SARS patients experienced more PTSS.\n\n\nConclusions\nAs expected, HCWs who were working in high-risk units experienced greater distress.\n\n Contrary to expectations, HCWs who experienced greater contact with SARS patients while working in the high-risk units were less distressed.\n\n This suggests that HCW experience in treating patients infected with SARS may be a mediating factor that could be amenable to intervention in future outbreaks.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7094601","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rima","surname":"Styra","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Laura","surname":"Hawryluck","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Susan","surname":"Robinson","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sonja","surname":"Kasapinovic","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Calvin","surname":"Fones","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wayne for insomnia (eCBTI) to prevent the transition from episodic insomnia to persistent insomnia: study protocol for a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Introduction\nPrevious evidence suggested that online self-guided sleep intervention is efficacious in improving treatment outcomes in patients with persistent insomnia.\n\n However, research on online sleep interventions targeting episodic insomnia has been scarce.\n\n This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of brief e-aid cognitive behavioural therapy for insomnia (eCBTI) in preventing transition from episodic insomnia to persistent insomnia.\n\n\nMethods and analysis\nThis is a pragmatic two-arm multicentre, randomised controlled trial comparing eCBTI with treatment as usual (TAU) in outpatients.\n\n Two hundred patients with episodic insomnia (as defined by DSM-5) will be recruited.\n\n Patients will be randomly assigned to receive 1?week eCBTI via a Smartphone application, or to receive TAU.\n\n Treatment effects will be assessed at 1?week and 3 months after intervention.\n\n The primary outcome of the study, whether the eCBTI program is sufficient in preventing transition from short-term to persistent insomnia, is measured by the Insomnia Severity Index.\n\n Secondary outcome measurements include the Dysfunctional Beliefs and Attitudes about Sleep Scale, Ford Insomnia Response to Stress Test, Sleep Hygiene and Practices Scale, Pre-sleep Arousal Scale and Epworth Sleepiness Scale.\n\n Additionally, the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale and the Short-Form 12-Item Health Survey will be used for measurement of mood symptoms and quality of life.\n\n\nEthics and dissemination\nEthical approval for the study has been obtained from the Ethics Committee of Southern Medical University (reference number: NFEC-2017131).\n\n The results of the investigation will be published in scientific papers.\n\n The data from the investigation will be made available online if necessary.\n\n\nTrial 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12874-020-00975-3","date":"2020-04-12","title":"How are systematic reviews of prevalence conducted? A methodological study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>There is a notable lack of methodological and reporting guidance for systematic reviews of prevalence data.\n\n This information void has the potential to result in reviews that are inconsistent and inadequate to inform healthcare policy and decision making.\n\n The aim of this meta-epidemiological study is to describe the methodology of recently published prevalence systematic reviews.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>We searched MEDLINE (via PubMed) from February 2017 to February 2018 for systematic reviews of prevalence studies.\n\n We included systematic reviews assessing the prevalence of any clinical condition using patients as the unit of measurement and we summarized data related to reporting and methodology of the reviews.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>A total of 235 systematic reviews of prevalence were analyzed.\n\n The median number of authors was 5 (interquartile range [IQR] 47), the median number of databases searched was 4 (36) and the median number of studies included in each review was 24 (IQR 1541.5).\n\n Search strategies were presented for 68% of reviews.\n\n Forty five percent of reviews received external funding, and 24% did not provide funding information.\n\n Twenty three percent of included reviews had published or registered the systematic review protocol.\n\n Reporting guidelines were used in 72% of reviews.\n\n The quality of included studies was assessed in 80% of reviews.\n\n Nine reviews assessed the overall quality of evidence (4 using GRADE).\n\n Meta-analysis was conducted in 65% of reviews; 1% used Bayesian methods.\n\n Random effect meta-analysis was used in 94% of reviews; among them, 75% did not report the variance estimator used.\n\n Among the reviews with meta-analysis, 70% did not report how data was transformed; 59% percent conducted subgroup analysis, 38% conducted meta-regression and 2% estimated prediction interval; I2 was estimated in 95% of analysis.\n\n Publication bias was examined in 48%.\n\n The most common software used was STATA (55%).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>Our results indicate that there are significant inconsistencies regarding how these reviews are conducted.\n\n Many of these differences arose in the assessment of methodological quality and the formal synthesis of comparable data.\n\n This variability indicates the need for clearer reporting standards and consensus on methodological guidance for systematic reviews of prevalence data.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7184711","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Celina","surname":"Borges found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2288-8-79","date":"2008-11-27","title":"Undue reliance on <italic>I</italic><sup>2 </sup>in assessing heterogeneity may mislead","abstract":"Background\nThe heterogeneity statistic I2, interpreted as the percentage of variability due to heterogeneity between studies rather than sampling error, depends on precision, that is, the size of the studies included.\n\n\nMethods\nBased on a real meta-analysis, we simulate artificially 'inflating' the sample size under the random effects model.\n\n For a given inflation factor M = 1, 2, 3,.\n\n.\n\n.\n\n and for each trial i, we create a M-inflated trial by drawing a treatment effect estimate from the random effects model, using si2/M as within-trial sampling variance.\n\n\nResults\nAs precision increases, while estimates of the heterogeneity variance ?2 remain unchanged on average, estimates of I2 increase rapidly to nearly 100%.\n\n A similar phenomenon is apparent in a sample of 157 meta-analyses.\n\n\nConclusion\nWhen deciding whether or not to pool treatment estimates in a meta-analysis, the yard-stick should be the clinical relevance of any heterogeneity present.\n\n ?2, rather than I2, is the appropriate measure for this purpose.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2648991","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gerta","surname":"Rücker","email":"ruecker@imbi.uni-freiburg.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guido","surname":"Schwarzer","email":"sc@imbi.uni-freiburg.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"James of meta-analysis: I2 is not an absolute measure of heterogeneity","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjopen-2015-010247","date":"2016-04-14","title":"Plea for routinely presenting prediction intervals in meta-analysis","abstract":"Objectives\nEvaluating the variation in the strength of the effect across studies is a key feature of meta-analyses.\n\n This variability is reflected by measures like ?2 or I2, but their clinical interpretation is not straightforward.\n\n A prediction interval is less complicated: it presents the expected range of true effects in similar studies.\n\n We aimed to show the advantages of having the prediction interval routinely reported in meta-analyses.\n\n\nDesign\nWe show how the prediction interval can help understand the uncertainty about whether an intervention works or not.\n\n To evaluate the implications of using this interval to interpret the results, we selected the first meta-analysis per intervention review of the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews Issues 20092013 with a dichotomous (n=2009) or continuous (n=1254) outcome, and generated 95% prediction intervals for them.\n\n\nResults\nIn 72.4% of 479 statistically significant (random-effects p&lt;0.05) meta-analyses in the Cochrane Database 20092013 with heterogeneity (I2&gt;0), the 95% prediction interval suggested that the intervention effect could be null or even be in the opposite direction.\n\n In 20.3% of those 479 meta-analyses, the prediction interval showed that the effect could be completely opposite to the point estimate of the meta-analysis.\n\n We demonstrate also how the prediction interval can be used to calculate the probability that a new trial will show a negative effect and to improve the calculations of the power of a new trial.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe prediction interval reflects the variation in treatment effects over different settings, including what effect is to be expected in future patients, such as the patients that a clinician is interested to treat.\n\n Prediction intervals should be routinely reported to allow more informative inferences in meta-analyses.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4947751","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Joanna","surname":"IntHout","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"John P suicidal thoughts and behaviors in Spanish university students. Results of the WHO World Mental Health- International College Student initiative","abstract":"Objective\nTo assess the accuracy of WMH-ICS online screening scales for evaluating four common mental disorders (Major Depressive Episode[MDE], Mania/Hypomania[M/H], Panic Disorder[PD], Generalized Anxiety Disorder[GAD]) and suicidal thoughts and behaviors[STB] used in the UNIVERSAL project.\n\n\nMethods\nClinical diagnostic reappraisal was carried out on a subsample of the UNIVERSAL project, a longitudinal online survey of first year Spanish students (1824 years old), part of the WHO World Mental Health-International College Student (WMH-ICS) initiative.\n\n Lifetime and 12-month prevalence of MDE, M/H, PD, GAD and STB were assessed with the Composite International Diagnostic Interview-Screening Scales [CIDI-SC], the Self-Injurious Thoughts and Behaviors Interview [SITBI] and the Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale [C-SSRS].\n\n Trained clinical psychologists, blinded to responses in the initial survey, administered via telephone the Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview [MINI].\n\n Measures of diagnostic accuracy and McNemar ?2 test were calculated.\n\n Sensitivity analyses were conducted to maximize diagnostic capacity.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 287 students were included in the clinical reappraisal study.\n\n For 12-month and lifetime mood disorders, sensitivity/specificity were 67%/88.6% and 65%/73.3%, respectively.\n\n For 12-month and lifetime anxiety disorders, these were 76.8%/86.5% and 59.6%/71.1%, and for 12-month and lifetime STB, 75.9%/94.8% and 87.2%/86.3%.\n\n For 12-month and lifetime mood disorders, anxiety disorders and STB, positive predictive values were in the range of 18.155.1% and negative predictive values 90.299.0%; likelihood ratios positive were in the range of 2.114.6 and likelihood ratios negative 0.10.6. All outcomes showed adequate areas under the curve [AUCs] (AUC&gt;0.7), except M/H and PD (AUC = 0.6).\n\n Post hoc analyses to select optimal diagnostic thresholds led to improved concordance for all diagnoses (AUCs&gt;0.8).\n\n\nConclusion\nThe WMS-ICS survey showed reasonable concordance with the MINI telephone interviews performed by mental health professionals, when utilizing optimized cut-off scores.\n\n The current study provides initial evidence that the WMS-ICS survey might be useful for screening purposes.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6728025","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Laura","surname":"Ballester","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Itxaso","surname":"Alayo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Itxaso","surname":"Alayo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gemma","surname":"Vilagut","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gemma","surname":"Vilagut","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"José","surname":"Almenara","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ana found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0156939","date":"2016-05-23","title":"Validated Screening Tools for Common Mental Disorders in Low and Middle Income Countries: A Systematic Review","abstract":"Background\nA wide range of screening tools are available to detect common mental disorders (CMDs), but few have been specifically developed for populations in low and middle income countries (LMIC).\n\n Cross-cultural application of a screening tool requires that its validity be assessed against a gold standard diagnostic interview.\n\n Validation studies of brief CMD screening tools have been conducted in several LMIC, but until now there has been no review of screening tools for all CMDs across all LMIC populations.\n\n\nMethods\nA systematic review with broad inclusion criteria was conducted, producing a comprehensive summary of brief CMD screening tools validated for use in LMIC populations.\n\n For each validation, the diagnostic odds ratio (DOR) was calculated as an easily comparable measure of screening tool validity.\n\n Average DOR results weighted by sample size were calculated for each screening tool, enabling us to make broad recommendations about best performing screening tools.\n\n\nResults\n153 studies fulfilled our inclusion criteria.\n\n Because many studies validated two or more screening tools, this corresponded to 273 separate validations against gold standard diagnostic criteria.\n\n We found that the validity of every screening tool tested in multiple settings and populations varied between studies, highlighting the importance of local validation.\n\n Many of the best performing tools were purposely developed for a specific population; however, as these tools have only been validated in one study, it is not possible to draw broader conclusions about their applicability in other contexts.\n\n\nConclusions\nOf the tools that have been validated in multiple settings, the authors broadly recommend using the SRQ-20 to screen for general CMDs, the GHQ-12 for CMDs in populations with physical illness, the HADS-D for depressive disorders, the PHQ-9 for depressive disorders in populations with good literacy levels, the EPDS for perinatal depressive disorders, and the HADS-A for anxiety disorders.\n\n We recommend that, wherever possible, a chosen screening tool should be validated against a gold standard diagnostic assessment in the specific context in which it will be employed.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4911088","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gemma-Claire","surname":"Ali","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Grace","surname":"Ryan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Grace","surname":"Ryan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mary Schedule","abstract":"Background\nDiagnosis of depressive disorder using interviewer-administered instruments is expensive and frequently impractical in large epidemiological surveys.\n\n The aim of this study was to assess the validity of three self-completion measures of depressive disorder and other psychiatric disorders in older people against an interviewer-administered instrument.\n\n\nMethod\nA random sample stratified by sex, age and social position was selected from the Whitehall II study participants.\n\n This sample was supplemented by inclusion of depressed Whitehall II participants.\n\n Depressive disorder and other mental disorders were assessed by the interviewer-administered structured revised Clinical Interview Schedule (CIS-R) in 277 participants aged 5880 years.\n\n Participants also completed a computerized self-completion version of the CIS-R in addition to the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ) and the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D).\n\n\nResults\nThe mean total score was similar for the interviewer-administered (4.43) and self-completion (4.35) versions of the CIS-R [95% confidence interval (CI) for difference ?0.31 to 0.16].\n\n Differences were not related to sex, age, social position or presence of chronic physical illness.\n\n Sensitivity/specificity of self-completion CIS-R was 74%/98% for any mental disorder and 75%/98% for depressive episode.\n\n The corresponding figures were 86%/87% and 78%/83% for GHQ and 77%/89% and 89%/86% for CES-D.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe self-completion computerized version of the CIS-R is feasible and has good validity as a measure of any mental disorder and depression in people aged ? 60 years.\n\n GHQ and CES-D also have good criterion validity as measures of any mental disorder and depressive disorder university students in four European countries  Study protocol for a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Background\nMental disorders and their symptoms are highly prevalent in the university student population, and the transition from secondary to tertiary education is associated with a rise in mental health problems.\n\n Existing web-based interventions for the prevention of common mental disorders in student populations often focus on just one disorder and have not been designed specifically for students.\n\n There is thus a need for transdiagnostic, student-specific preventative interventions that can be widely disseminated.\n\n This two-arm, parallel group randomised controlled trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a web-based transdiagnostic mental health problem prevention programme (PLUS) across several universities in four countries.\n\n\nMethod\nStudents (N?=?5550) will be recruited through a variety of channels and asked to complete a personality assessment to determine whether they are at high risk for developing common mental disorders.\n\n Students at high risk will be randomly allocated to either PLUS or a control intervention, which provides practical support around issues commonly experienced at university.\n\n Students at low risk will be allocated to the control intervention.\n\n Both intervention groups will be assessed at baseline, 4?weeks, 3?months, 6?months and 12?months after randomisation.\n\n Depression and generalised anxiety, assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire and the Generalised Anxiety Disorder scales, will form the primary outcomes in this study.\n\n Secondary outcome measures include alcohol and drug use, eating behaviour, self-esteem, and quality of life.\n\n The cost-effectiveness of the intervention will also be evaluated.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study will contribute to understanding the role of transdiagnostic indicated web-based interventions for the prevention of common mental disorders in university students.\n\n It will also be one of the first studies to investigate the cost-effectiveness of such interventions.\n\n\nTrial Registration\nThis trial was registered in the ISRCTN register (ISRCTN15570935) on 12th February found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1213/ANE.0000000000003698","date":"2018-07-03","title":"Diagnostic Testing and Decision-Making: Beauty Is Not Just in the Eye of the Beholder","abstract":"To use a diagnostic test effectively and consistently in their practice, clinicians need to know how well the test distinguishes between those patients who have the suspected acute or chronic disease and those patients who do not.\n Clinicians are equally interested and usually more concerned whether, based on the results of a screening test, a given patient actually: (1) does or does not have the suspected disease; or (2) will or will not subsequently experience the adverse event or outcome.\n Medical tests that are performed to screen for a risk factor, diagnose a disease, or to estimate a patients prognosis are frequently a key component of a clinical research study.\n Like therapeutic interventions, medical tests require proper analysis and demonstrated efficacy before being incorporated into routine clinical practice.\n This basic statistical tutorial, thus, discusses the fundamental concepts and techniques related to diagnostic testing and medical decision-making, including sensitivity and specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value, positive and negative likelihood ratio, receiver operating characteristic curve, diagnostic accuracy, choosing a best cut-point for a continuous variable biomarker, comparing methods on diagnostic accuracy, and design of a diagnostic accuracy study.\n","id":"PMC6135476","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Thomas found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]}]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjopen-2017-019305","date":"2017-11-29","title":"Online versus paper-based screening for depression and anxiety in adults with cystic fibrosis in Ireland: a cross-sectional exploratory study","abstract":"Objective\nTo compare online and paper-based screening for depression and anxiety in adults with cystic fibrosis (CF).\n\n\nDesign and setting\nCross-sectional study in CF clinics in Ireland and through the Cystic Fibrosis Ireland online community.\n\n\nParticipants\n160 adult patients aged 18 or above were recruited.\n\n Of these, 147 were included in the analysis; 83 online and 64 paper-based.\n\n The remaining 13 were excluded because of incomplete data.\n\n\nMeasures\nDepression and anxiety were measured using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS).\n\n Data on pulmonary function (forced expiratory volume in 1 s %) and body mass index were self-reported based on clinical assessments.\n\n Sociodemographic data were collected.\n\n\nResults\nCompared with the paper-based participants, the online participants were more likely to be female (61.7% vs 48.4%), older (mean 32.2 vs 28.2 years) and were more likely to be married (32.5% vs 15.6%), living with their spouse or partner (42.5% vs 22.6%) and working either full time (33.7% vs 15.9%) or part time (30.1%vs 17.5%).\n\n The prevalence rates of elevated anxiety and depression were not significantly different (P=0.71 and P=0.56).\n\n HADS anxiety and depression scores were not statistically different between online (P=0.83) and paper-based (P=0.92) participants based on Mann-Whitney U test.\n\n A significant negative correlation was found between depression and pulmonary function (r=?0.39, P=0.01) and anxiety and pulmonary function (r=?0.36, P=0.02).\n\n Based on Cronbachs alpha, there were no statistically significant differences between the online and paper-based participants on the internal consistency of the HADS anxiety (P=0.073) and depression (P=0.378) scales.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur findings suggest that online and paper-based screening for depression and anxiety in adult patients with CF yield comparable findings on prevalence rates and scores, associations with health and internal consistency of subscales.\n\n This study highlights that online screening offers an alternative method to paper-based screening.\n\n Further research with a larger sample and assessment of measurement equivalence between online and paper based screening is needed to confirm our results.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5781152","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jennifer","surname":"Cronly","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Alistair anxiety","abstract":"Studies measuring psychological distress in individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF) have found high rates of both depression and anxiety.\n Psychological symptoms in both individuals with CF and parent caregivers have been associated with decreased lung function, lower body mass index, worse adherence, worse health-related quality of life, more frequent hospitalisations and increased healthcare costs.\n To identify and treat depression and anxiety in CF, the CF Foundation and the European CF Society invited a panel of experts, including physicians, psychologists, psychiatrists, nurses, social workers, a pharmacist, parents and an individual with CF, to develop consensus recommendations for clinical care.\n Over 18?months, this 22-member committee was divided into four workgroups: Screening; Psychological Interventions; Pharmacological Treatments and Implementation and Future Research, and used the Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome methodology to develop questions for literature search and review.\n Searches were conducted in PubMed, PsychINFO, ScienceDirect, Google Scholar, Psychiatry online and ABDATA by a methodologist at Dartmouth.\n The committee reviewed 344 articles, drafted statements and set an 80% acceptance for each recommendation statement as a consensus threshold prior to an anonymous voting process.\n Fifteen guideline recommendation statements for screening and treatment of depression and anxiety in individuals with CF and parent caregivers were finalised by vote.\n As these recommendations are implemented in CF centres internationally, the process of dissemination, implementation and resource provision should be closely monitored to assess barriers and concerns, validity and use.\n","id":"PMC4717439","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Alexandra found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/jmir.1392","date":"2010-04-14","title":"A Comparison of Psychometric Properties Between Internet and Paper Versions of Two Depression Instruments (BDI-II and MADRS-S) Administered to Clinic Patients","abstract":"Background\nSelf-report measures can guide clinical decisions and are useful when evaluating treatment outcomes.\n\n However, many clinicians do not use self-report measures systematically in their clinical practice.\n\n Internet-based questionnaires could facilitate administration, but the psychometric properties of the online version of an instrument should be explored before implementation.\n\n The recommendation from the International Test Commission is to test the psychometric properties of each questionnaire separately.\n\n\nObjective\nOur objective was to compare the psychometric properties of paper-and-pencil versions and Internet versions of two questionnaires measuring depressive symptoms.\n\n\nMethods\nThe 87 participating patients were recruited from primary care and psychiatric care within the public health care system in Sweden.\n\n Participants completed the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II) and the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating ScaleSelf-rated (MADRS-S), both on paper and on the Internet.\n\n The order was randomized to control for order effects.\n\n Symptom severity in the sample ranged from mild to severe depressive symptoms.\n\n\nResults\nPsychometric properties of the two administration formats were mostly equivalent.\n\n The internal consistency was similar for the Internet and paper versions, and significant correlations were found between the formats for both MADRS-S (r = .\n\n84) and the BDI-II (r = .\n\n89).\n\n Differences between paper and Internet total scores were not statistically significant for either questionnaire nor for the MADRS-S question dealing with suicidality (item 9) when analyzed separately.\n\n The score on the BDI-II question about suicidality (item 9) was significantly lower when administered via the Internet compared with the paper score, but the difference was small (effect size, Cohens [d] = 0.14).\n\n There were significant main effects for order of administration on both questionnaires and significant interaction effects between format and order.\n\n This should not, however, pose a problem in clinical use as long as the administration format is not changed when repeated measurements are made.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe MADRS-S can be transferred to online use without affecting the psychometric properties in a clinically meaningful way.\n\n The full BDI-II also seems to retain its properties when transferred; however, the item measuring suicidality in the Internet version needs further investigation since it was associated with a lower score in this study.\n\n The use of online questionnaires offers clinicians a more practical way of measuring depressive symptoms and has the potential to save resources.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3057311","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Pim","surname":"Cuijpers","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kate","surname":"Cavanagh","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kate","surname":"Cavanagh","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Frances","surname":"Kay-Lambkin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Fredrik","surname":"Holländare","email":"fredrik.hollandare@orebroll.se","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Fredrik","surname":"Holländare","email":"fredrik.hollandare@orebroll.se","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gerhard","surname":"Andersson","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ingemar","surname":"Engström","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1002/gps.3993","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Piloting found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/jmir.9.1.e2","date":"2006-12-28","title":"Psychological Assessment via the Internet: A Reliability and Validity Study of Online (vs Paper-and-Pencil) Versions of the General Health Questionnaire-28 (GHQ-28) and the Symptoms Check-List-90-Revised (SCL-90-R)","abstract":"Background\n Internet psychology services are rapidly increasing and that implies online assessment.\n\n To guarantee the results of these new online evaluation procedures, it is necessary to have reliable and valid assessment tools.\n\n\nObjective\n In this work we analyzed the online versions of two popular psychopathology screening questionnaires: the General Health Questionnaire-28 (GHQ-28) and the Symptoms Check-List-90-Revised (SCL-90-R).\n\n\nMethods\n A total of 185 psychology students were recruited from two universities in Madrid, Spain.\n\n All of them had Internet access at home.\n\n A test-retest situation and factorial analysis were used to generate reliability and validity data.\n\n Both paper-and-pencil questionnaires (test) and their online versions (retest) were completed by 100 participants (median gap = 17 days).\n\n\nResults\n Results suggest that both online questionnaires were fairly equivalent to their paper-and-pencil versions, with higher reliability values for the SCL-90-R.\n\n Factorial analysis tended to reproduce the structure shown in former investigations of both questionnaires, replicating the four-factor structure of the GHQ-28 but failing to do so with the nine-factor structure of the SCL-90-R.\n\n Instead, a large unrotated factor appeared.\n\n\nConclusions\n Further research should be carried out to confirm these data, but our work supports the online use of both assessment tools.\n\n The psychometric properties of the online version of GHQ-28 is similar to the paper-and-pencil and we can recommend its utilization in a Web environment.\n\n In contrast, SCL-90-R can only be recommended as a global index for psychological distress, using the Global Severity Index (GSI), not necessarily its subscales; and it should be considered that the online scores were lower than the ones with the paper-and-pencil version.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1794673","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Miguel help-seeking for mental health problems: population-based randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Background\nCommunity-based screening for mental health problems may increase service use through feedback to individuals about their severity of symptoms and provision of contacts for appropriate services.\n\n\nAims\nThe effect of symptom feedback on service use was assessed.\n\n Secondary outcomes included symptom change and study attrition.\n\n\nMethod\nUsing online recruitment, 2773 participants completed a comprehensive survey including screening for depression (n=1366) or social anxiety (n=1407).\n\n Across these two versions, approximately half (n=1342) of the participants were then randomly allocated to receive tailored feedback.\n\n Participants were reassessed after 3 months (Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ANZCTR12614000324617).\n\n\nResults\nA negative effect of providing social anxiety feedback to individuals was observed, with significant reductions in professional service use.\n\n Greater attrition and lower intentions to seek help were also observed after feedback.\n\n\nConclusions\nOnline mental health screening with feedback is not effective for promoting professional service use.\n\n Alternative models of online screening require further investigation.\n\n\nDeclaration of interest\nNone.\n\n\nCopyright and usage\n© The Royal 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12874-019-0782-0","date":"2019-06-20","title":"Single screening versus conventional double screening for study selection in systematic reviews: a methodological systematic review","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Stringent requirements exist regarding the transparency of the study selection process and the reliability of results.\n\n A 2-step selection process is generally recommended; this is conducted by 2 reviewers independently of each other (conventional double-screening).\n\n However, the approach is resource intensive, which can be a problem, as systematic reviews generally need to be completed within a defined period with a limited budget.\n\n The aim of the following methodological systematic review was to analyse the evidence available on whether single screening is equivalent to double screening in the screening process conducted in systematic reviews.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>We searched Medline, PubMed and the Cochrane Methodology Register (last search 10/2018).\n\n We also used supplementary search techniques and sources (similar articles function in PubMed, conference abstracts and reference lists).\n\n We included all evaluations comparing single with double screening.\n\n Data were summarized in a structured, narrative way.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The 4 evaluations included investigated a total of 23 single screenings (12 sets for screening involving 9 reviewers).\n\n The median proportion of missed studies was 5% (range 0 to 58%).\n\n The median proportion of missed studies was 3% for the 6 experienced reviewers (range: 0 to 21%) and 13% for the 3 reviewers with less experience (range: 0 to 58%).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par5'>Single screening of the titles and abstracts of studies retrieved in bibliographic searches is not equivalent to double screening, as substantially more studies are missed.\n\n However, in our opinion such an approach could still represent an appropriate methodological shortcut in rapid reviews, as long as it is conducted by an experienced reviewer.\n\n Further research on single screening is required, for instance, regarding factors influencing the number of studies missed.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (10.1186/s12874-019-0782-0) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6599339","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Siw","surname":"Waffenschmidt","email":"siw.waffenschmidt@iqwig.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marco","surname":"Knelangen","email":"marco.knelangen@iqwig.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marco","surname":"Knelangen","email":"marco.knelangen@iqwig.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wiebke","surname":"Sieben","email":"wiebke.sieben@iqwig.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Stefanie","surname":"Bühn","email":"Stefanie.Buehn@uni-wh.de","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Dawid","surname":"Pieper","email":"Dawid.Pieper@uni-wh.de","contributions":"0"}],"References depth 2":[{"doi":"10.1186/2046-4053-4-5","date":"2014-12-10","title":"Using text mining for study identification in systematic reviews: a systematic review of current approaches","abstract":"Background\nThe large and growing number of published studies, and their increasing rate of publication, makes the task of identifying relevant studies in an unbiased way for inclusion in systematic reviews both complex and time consuming.\n\n Text mining has been offered as a potential solution: through automating some of the screening process, reviewer time can be saved.\n\n The evidence base around the use of text mining for screening has not yet been pulled together systematically; this systematic review fills that research gap.\n\n Focusing mainly on non-technical issues, the review aims to increase awareness of the potential of these technologies and promote further collaborative research between the computer science and systematic review communities.\n\n\nMethods\nFive research questions led our review: what is the state of the evidence base; how has workload reduction been evaluated; what are the purposes of semi-automation and how effective are they; how have key contextual problems of applying text mining to the systematic review field been addressed; and what challenges to implementation have emerged?\nResults\nThe evidence base is active and diverse; there is almost no replication between studies or collaboration between research teams and, whilst it is difficult to establish any overall conclusions about best approaches, it is clear that efficiencies and reductions in workload are potentially achievable.\n\n\nConclusions\nUsing text mining to prioritise the order in which items are screened should be considered safe and ready for use in live reviews.\n\n The use of text mining as a second screener may also be used cautiously.\n\n The use of text mining to eliminate studies automatically should be considered promising, but not yet fully proven.\n\n In highly technical/clinical areas, it may be used with a high degree of confidence; but more developmental and evaluative work is needed in other disciplines.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/2046-4053-4-5) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4320539","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Alison","surname":"OMara-Eves","email":"a.omara-eves@ioe.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"James","surname":"Thomas","email":"j.thomas@ioe.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"John","surname":"McNaught","email":"John.McNaught@manchester.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Makoto","surname":"Miwa","email":"makoto-miwa@toyota-ti.ac.jp","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sophia","surname":"Ananiadou","email":"Sophia.Ananiadou@manchester.ac.uk","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1002/jrsm.1237","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Can Rockville, MD: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality; 2013. https://effectivehealthcare.ahrq.gov/sites/default/files/pdf/methods-guidance-bias_methods.pdf.","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13643-016-0360-z","date":"2016-10-18","title":"Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group to play a leading role in guiding the production of informed high-quality, timely research evidence syntheses","abstract":"Background\nPolicymakers and healthcare stakeholders are increasingly seeking evidence to inform the policymaking process, and often use existing or commissioned systematic reviews to inform decisions.\n\n However, the methodologies that make systematic reviews authoritative take time, typically 1 to 2 years to complete.\n\n Outside the traditional SR timeline, rapid reviews have emerged as an efficient tool to get evidence to decision-makers more quickly.\n\n However, the use of rapid reviews does present challenges.\n\n To date, there has been limited published empirical information about this approach to compiling evidence.\n\n Thus, it remains a poorly understood and ill-defined set of diverse methodologies with various labels.\n\n In recent years, the need to further explore rapid review methods, characteristics, and their use has been recognized by a growing network of healthcare researchers, policymakers, and organizations, several with ties to Cochrane, which is recognized as representing an international gold standard for high-quality, systematic reviews.\n\n\nPurpose\nIn this commentary, we introduce the newly established Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group developed to play a leading role in guiding the production of rapid reviews given they are increasingly employed as a research synthesis tool to support timely evidence-informed decision-making.\n\n We discuss how the group was formed and outline the groups structure and remit.\n\n We also discuss the need to establish a more robust evidence base for rapid reviews in the published literature, and the importance of promoting registration of rapid review protocols in an effort to promote efficiency and transparency in research.\n\n\nConclusion\nAs with standard systematic reviews, the core principles of evidence-based synthesis should apply to rapid reviews in order to minimize bias to the extent possible.\n\n The Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group will serve to establish a network of rapid review stakeholders and provide a forum for discussion and training.\n\n By facilitating exchange, the group will strive to conduct research to advance the methods of rapid reviews.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5084365","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Chantelle","surname":"Garritty","email":"cgarritty@ohri.ca","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Adrienne","surname":"Stevens","email":"adstevens@ohri.ca","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gerald","surname":"Gartlehner","email":"gerald.gartlehner@donau-uni.ac.at","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Valerie","surname":"King","email":"kingv@ohsu.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chris","surname":"Kamel","email":"chrisk@cadth.ca","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12961-016-0155-7","date":"2016-11-02","title":"What are the best methodologies for rapid reviews of the research evidence for evidence-informed decision making in health policy and practice: a rapid review","abstract":"Background\nRapid reviews have the potential to overcome a key barrier to the use of research evidence in decision making, namely that of the lack of timely and relevant research.\n\n This rapid review of systematic reviews and primary studies sought to answer the question: What are the best methodologies to enable a rapid review of research evidence for evidence-informed decision making in health policy and practice?\nMethods\nThis rapid review utilised systematic review methods and was conducted according to a pre-defined protocol including clear inclusion criteria (PROSPERO registration: CRD42015015998).\n\n A comprehensive search strategy was used, including published and grey literature, written in English, French, Portuguese or Spanish, from 2004 onwards.\n\n Eleven databases and two websites were searched.\n\n Two review authors independently applied the eligibility criteria.\n\n Data extraction was done by one reviewer and checked by a second.\n\n The methodological quality of included studies was assessed independently by two reviewers.\n\n A narrative summary of the results is presented.\n\n\nResults\nFive systematic reviews and one randomised controlled trial (RCT) that investigated methodologies for rapid reviews met the inclusion criteria.\n\n None of the systematic reviews were of sufficient quality to allow firm conclusions to be made.\n\n Thus, the findings need to be treated with caution.\n\n There is no agreed definition of rapid reviews in the literature and no agreed methodology for conducting rapid reviews.\n\n While a wide range of shortcuts are used to make rapid reviews faster than a full systematic review, the included studies found little empirical evidence of their impact on the conclusions of either rapid or systematic reviews.\n\n There is some evidence from the included RCT (that had a low risk of bias) that rapid reviews may improve clarity and accessibility of research evidence for decision makers.\n\n\nConclusions\nGreater care needs to be taken in improving the transparency of the methods used in rapid review products.\n\n There is no evidence available to suggest that rapid reviews should not be done or that they are misleading in any way.\n\n We offer an improved definition of rapid reviews to guide future research as well as clearer guidance for policy and practice.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s12961-016-0155-7) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5123411","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Michelle M.","surname":"Haby","email":"haby@unimelb.edu.au","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Evelina","surname":"Chapman","email":"evelinachap@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rachel","surname":"Clark","email":"rachel.x.clark@phe.gov.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jorge","surname":"Barreto","email":"jorgebarreto@fiocruz.br","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ludovic","surname":"Reveiz","email":"reveizl@paho.org","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"John N.","surname":"Lavis","email":"lavisj@mcmaster.ca","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12874-016-0216-1","date":"2016-08-17","title":"The use of rapid review methods in health technology assessments: 3 case studies","abstract":"Background\nRapid reviews are of increasing importance within health technology assessment due to time and resource constraints.\n\n There are many rapid review methods available although there is little guidance as to the most suitable methods.\n\n We present three case studies employing differing methods to suit the evidence base for each review and outline some issues to consider when selecting an appropriate method.\n\n\nMethods\nThree recently completed systematic review short reports produced for the UK National Institute for Health Research were examined.\n\n Different approaches to rapid review methods were used in the three reports which were undertaken to inform the commissioning of services within the NHS and to inform future trial design.\n\n We describe the methods used, the reasoning behind the choice of methods and explore the strengths and weaknesses of each method.\n\n\nResults\nRapid review methods were chosen to meet the needs of the review and each review had distinctly different challenges such as heterogeneity in terms of populations, interventions, comparators and outcome measures (PICO) and/or large numbers of relevant trials.\n\n All reviews included at least 10 randomised controlled trials (RCTs), each with numerous included outcomes.\n\n For the first case study (sexual health interventions), very diverse studies in terms of PICO were included.\n\n P-values and summary information only were presented due to substantial heterogeneity between studies and outcomes measured.\n\n For the second case study (premature ejaculation treatments), there were over 100 RCTs but also several existing systematic reviews.\n\n Data for meta-analyses were extracted directly from existing systematic reviews with new RCT data added where available.\n\n For the final case study (cannabis cessation therapies), studies included a wide range of interventions and considerable variation in study populations and outcomes.\n\n A brief summary of the key findings for each study was presented and narrative synthesis used to summarise results for each pair of interventions compared.\n\n\nConclusions\nRapid review methods need to be chosen to meet both the nature of the evidence base of a review and the challenges presented by the included studies.\n\n Appropriate methods should be chosen after an assessment of the evidence base.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5000433","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Eva","surname":"Kaltenthaler","email":"e.kaltenthaler@sheffield.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Katy","surname":"Cooper","email":"k.l.cooper@sheffield.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Katy","surname":"Cooper","email":"k.l.cooper@sheffield.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Abdullah","surname":"Pandor","email":"a.pandor@sheffield.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marrissa","surname":"Martyn-St. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13643-016-0315-4","date":"2016-08-04","title":"Use of cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the efficiency of study identification methods in systematic reviews","abstract":"Background\nMeta-research studies investigating methods, systems, and processes designed to improve the efficiency of systematic review workflows can contribute to building an evidence base that can help to increase value and reduce waste in research.\n\n This study demonstrates the use of an economic evaluation framework to compare the costs and effects of four variant approaches to identifying eligible studies for consideration in systematic reviews.\n\n\nMethods\nA cost-effectiveness analysis was conducted using a basic decision-analytic model, to compare the relative efficiency of safety first, double screening, single screening and single screening with text mining approaches in the title-abstract screening stage of a case study systematic review about undergraduate medical education in UK general practice settings.\n\n Incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs) were calculated as the incremental cost per citation saved from inappropriate exclusion from the review.\n\n Resource use and effect parameters were estimated based on retrospective analysis of review process meta-data curated alongside the case study review, in conjunction with retrospective simulation studies to model the integrated use of text mining.\n\n Unit cost parameters were estimated based on the case study reviews project budget.\n\n A base case analysis was conducted, with deterministic sensitivity analyses to investigate the impact of variations in values of key parameters.\n\n\nResults\nUse of single screening with text mining would have resulted in title-abstract screening workload reductions (base case analysis) of &gt;60 % compared with other approaches.\n\n Across modelled scenarios, the safety first approach was, consistently, equally effective and less costly than conventional double screening.\n\n Compared with single screening with text mining, estimated ICERs for the two non-dominated approaches (base case analyses) ranged from £1975 (single screening without a provisionally included code) to £4427 (safety first with a provisionally included code) per citation saved.\n\n Patterns of results were consistent between base case and sensitivity analyses.\n\n\nConclusions\nAlternatives to the conventional double screening approach, integrating text mining, warrant further consideration as potentially more efficient approaches to identifying eligible studies for systematic reviews.\n\n Comparable economic evaluations conducted using other systematic review datasets are needed to determine the generalisability of these findings and to build an evidence base to inform guidance for review authors.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4989498","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ian","surname":"Shemilt","email":"i.shemilt@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nada","surname":"Khan","email":"nada.khan@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sophie","surname":"Park","email":"sophie.park@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"James","surname":"Thomas","email":"james.thomas@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1002/jrsm.1215","date":"2016-05-09","title":"Implications review is an approach to synthesizing research evidence when a shorter timeframe is required.\n\n The implications of what is lost in terms of rigour, increased bias and accuracy when conducting a rapid review have not yet been elucidated.\n\n\nMethods\nid='jrsm1215-para-0004'>We assessed the potential implications of methodological shortcuts on the outcomes of three completed systematic reviews addressing agri?food public health topics.\n\n For each review, shortcuts were applied individually to assess the impact on the number of relevant studies included and whether omitted studies affected the direction, magnitude or precision of summary estimates from meta?analyses.\n\n\nResults\nid='jrsm1215-para-0005'>In most instances, the shortcuts resulted in at least one relevant study being omitted from the review.\n\n The omission of studies affected 39 of 143 possible meta?analyses, of which 14 were no longer possible because of insufficient studies (&lt;2).\n\n When meta?analysis was possible, the omission of studies generally resulted in less precise pooled estimates (i.\n\ne.\n\n wider confidence intervals) that did not differ in direction from the original estimate.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='jrsm1215-para-0006'>The three case studies demonstrated the risk of missing relevant literature and its impact on summary estimates when methodological shortcuts are the Psychological Impact of COVID-19 on Healthcare Workers: A Digital Learning Package","abstract":"The coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19) will undoubtedly have psychological impacts for healthcare workers, which could be sustained; frontline workers will be particularly at risk.\n Actions are needed to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on mental health by protecting and promoting the psychological wellbeing of healthcare workers during and after the outbreak.\n We developed and evaluated a digital learning package using Agile methodology within the first three weeks of UK outbreak.\n This e-package includes evidence-based guidance, support and signposting relating to psychological wellbeing for all UK healthcare employees.\n A three-step rapid development process included public involvement activities (PPIs) (STEP 1), content and technical development with iterative peer review (STEP 2), and delivery and evaluation (STEP 3).\n The package outlines the actions that team leaders can take to provide psychologically safe spaces for staff, together with guidance on communication and reducing social stigma, peer and family support, signposting others through psychological first aid (PFA), self-care strategies (e.\ng.\n, rest, work breaks, sleep, shift work, fatigue, healthy lifestyle behaviours), and managing emotions (e.\ng.\n, moral injury, coping, guilt, grief, fear, anxiety, depression, preventing burnout and psychological trauma).\n The e-package includes advice from experts in mental wellbeing as well as those with direct pandemic experiences from the frontline, as well as signposting to public mental health guidance.\n Rapid delivery in STEP 3 was achieved via direct emails through professional networks and social media.\n Evaluation included assessment of fidelity and implementation qualities.\n Essential content was identified through PPIs (n = 97) and peer review (n = 10) in STEPS 1 and 2. The most important messages to convey were deemed to be normalisation of psychological responses during a crisis, and encouragement of self-care and help-seeking behaviour.\n Within 7 days of completion, the package had been accessed 17,633 times, and healthcare providers had confirmed immediate adoption within their health and wellbeing provisions.\n Evaluation (STEP 3, n = 55) indicated high user satisfaction with content, usability and utility.\n Assessment of implementation qualities indicated that the package was perceived to be usable, practical, low cost and low burden.\n Our digital support package on psychological wellbeing for healthcare workers is free to use, has been positively evaluated and was highly accessed within one week of release.\n It is available here: Supplementary Materials.\n This package was deemed to be appropriate, meaningful and useful for the needs of UK healthcare workers.\n We recommend provision of this e-package to healthcare workers Warn","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2334-10-322","date":"2010-11-09","title":"General hospital staff worries, perceived sufficiency of information and associated psychological distress during the A/H1N1 influenza pandemic","abstract":"Background\nHealth care workers (HCWs) presented frequent concerns regarding their health and their families' health and high levels of psychological distress during previous disease outbreaks, such as the SARS outbreak, which was associated with social isolation and intentional absenteeism.\n\n We aimed to assess HCWs concerns and anxiety, perceived sufficiency of information, and intended behavior during the recent A/H1N1 influenza pandemic and their associations with psychological distress.\n\n\nMethod\nBetween September 1st and 30th, 2009, 469 health-care workers (HCWs) of a tertiary teaching hospital completed a 20-item questionnaire regarding concerns and worries about the new A/H1N1 influenza pandemic, along with Cassileth's Information Styles Questionnaire (part-I) and the GHQ-28.\nResults\nMore than half of the present study's HCWs (56.7%) reported they were worried about the A/H1N1 influenza pandemic, their degree of anxiety being moderately high (median 6/9).\n\n The most frequent concern was infection of family and friends and the health consequences of the disease (54.9%).\n\n The perceived risk of being infected was considered moderately high (median 6/9).\n\n Few HCWs (6.6%) had restricted their social contacts and fewer (3.8%) felt isolated by their family members and friends because of their hospital work, while a low percentage (4.3%) indented to take a leave to avoid infection.\n\n However, worry and degree of worry were significantly associated with intended absenteeism (p &lt; 0.0005), restriction of social contacts (p &lt; 0.0005), and psychological distress (p = 0.036).\n\n Perceived sufficiency of information about several aspects of the A/H1N1 influenza was moderately high, and the overall information about the A/H1N1 influenza was considered clear (median 7.4/9).\n\n Also, perceived sufficiency of information for the prognosis of the infection was significantly independently associated with the degree of worry about the pandemic (p = 0.008).\n\n\nConclusions\nA significant proportion of HCWs experienced moderately high anxiety about the pandemic, and their degree of worry was an independent correlate of psychological distress.\n\n Since perceived sufficiency of information about the A/H1N1 influenza prognosis was associated with reduced degree of worry, hospital managers and consultation-liaison psychiatry services should try to provide for HCWs' need for information, in order to offer favourable working conditions in times of extreme distress, such as the current and future pandemics.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2990753","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Panagiota","surname":"Goulia","email":"panagiotagoulia@yahoo.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christos","surname":"Mantas","email":"chmantas@cc.uoi.gr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Danai","surname":"Dimitroula","email":"danaed75@otenet.gr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Dimitrios","surname":"Mantis","email":"mantisdi@otenet.gr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Thomas","surname":"Hyphantis","email":"tyfantis@cc.uoi.gr","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/occmed/kqh027","date":"2003-12-02","title":"Psychological found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/bs8110098","date":"2018-10-23","title":"Factors Related to Physician Burnout and Its Consequences: A Review","abstract":"Physician burnout is a universal dilemma that is seen in healthcare professionals, particularly physicians, and is characterized by emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and a feeling of low personal accomplishment.\n In this review, we discuss the contributing factors leading to physician burnout and its consequences for the physicians health, patient outcomes, and the healthcare system.\n Physicians face daily challenges in providing care to their patients, and burnout may be from increased stress levels in overworked physicians.\n Additionally, the healthcare system mandates physicians to keep a meticulous record of their physician-patient encounters along with clerical responsibilities.\n Physicians are not well-trained in managing clerical duties, and this might shift their focus from solely caring for their patients.\n This can be addressed by the systematic application of evidence-based interventions, including but not limited to group interventions, mindfulness training, assertiveness training, facilitated discussion groups, and promoting a healthy work environment.\n","id":"PMC6262585","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rikinkumar Health and Psychosocial Problems of Medical Health Workers during the COVID-19 Epidemic in China","abstract":"Objective\nWe explored whether medical health workers had more psychosocial problems than nonmedical health workers during the COVID-19 outbreak.\n\n\nMethods\nAn online survey was run from February 19 to March 6, 2020; a total of 2,182 Chinese subjects participated.\n\n Mental health variables were assessed via the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), the Symptom Check List-revised (SCL-90-R), and the Patient Health Questionnaire-4 (PHQ-4), which included a 2-item anxiety scale and a 2-item depression scale (PHQ-2).\n\n\nResults\nCompared with nonmedical health workers (n = 1,255), medical health workers (n = 927) had a higher prevalence of insomnia (38.4 vs.\n\n 30.5%, p &lt; 0.01), anxiety (13.0 vs.\n\n 8.5%, p &lt; 0.01), depression (12.2 vs.\n\n 9.5%; p&lt; 0.04), somatization (1.6 vs.\n\n 0.4%; p &lt; 0.01), and obsessive-compulsive symptoms (5.3 vs.\n\n 2.2%; p &lt; 0.01).\n\n They also had higher total scores of ISI, GAD-2, PHQ-2, and SCL-90-R obsessive-compulsive symptoms (p ? 0.01).\n\n Among medical health workers, having organic disease was an independent factor for insomnia, anxiety, depression, somatization, and obsessive-compulsive symptoms (p &lt; 0.05 or 0.01).\n\n Living in rural areas, being female, and being at risk of contact with COVID-19 patients were the most common risk factors for insomnia, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive symptoms, and depression (p &lt; 0.01 or 0.05).\n\n Among nonmedical health workers, having organic disease was a risk factor for insomnia, depression, and obsessive-compulsive symptoms (p &lt; 0.01 or 0.05).\n\n\nConclusions\nDuring the COVID-19 outbreak, medical health workers had psychosocial problems and risk factors for developing them.\n\n They were in need of attention and recovery programs.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7206349","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Wen-rui","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kun","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lu","surname":"Yin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wen-feng","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Qing","surname":"Xue","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mao","surname":"Peng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bao-quan","surname":"Min","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Qing","surname":"Tian","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hai-xia","surname":"Leng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jia-lin","surname":"Du","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong","surname":"Chang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuan","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wei","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Fang-fang","surname":"Shangguan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Tian-yi","surname":"Yan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hui-qing","surname":"Dong","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ying","surname":"Han","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yu-ping","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Fiammetta","surname":"Cosci","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong-xing","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Psychological
